characters: THE PACKET OF TRAVELERS CHECKS TO SHOW THE
DOWN FROM THE DECK OF THE LYNX
A SOUND OF FEET, A STAMP, A SLAPPING OF HANDS AGAINST RIF
SHOOTING FORWARD THROUGH THE WINDSHIELD OF THE CAR
BRANDON AND BETTY ON SIDEWALK IN FRONT OF CHARLIE'S.
THE PLANE DIVING DIRECTLY ON THE VALKYRI
THE POLICE CAR IN FRONT OF MAGRUDER'S.
SHOT THROUGH THE PLEXIGLAS HEAD AND SHOULDERS OF THE PILO
A PORTION OF GUARD MOUNT THROUGH RAILING
CAMERA MOVES IN ENOUGH TO SHOW WHAT HE IS READING
AN EMPTY TAXICAB, THE FLAG UP
SHOOTING FORWARD THROUGH POLICE CAR WINDSHIELD
MOVE IN TO SHOW THERE IS NO WRITING ON THE ENVELOPE
DRUM AND BUGLE MUSIC IN BACKGROUND STOPS.
HANGING IN THE SKY AND FALLING
A PORTION OF A TALL, SPEAR TOPPED IRON RAIL
A SOUND OF STAMPING FEET, THEN SILENCE.
FOOT OF STAIRS JUST INSIDE SWINGING DOORS
APPROPRIATE SOUNDS ARE HEARD, THEN A ROLL STARTS ON THE
GRAVELED OR PAVED SPACE IN FRONT OF MILITARY
THE INSIDE OF THE JACKET POCKET AND THE EXPOSED
SHOWING OPEN DOORS OF FOUR ROOMETTES
COAST GUARD CUTTER LYNX TRAVELING AT HIGH SPE
HE STARTS OUT, TURNS TO SAY,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A STREAMLINER coming TOWARDS CAMERA which is off to one  side of tracks. The landscape has pine and fir trees and  is a northern Washington landscape. As the streamliner passes, the CAMERA PANS around followi it and stops. The streamliner tears off into the distance and in the foreground is WE SEE a RAILROAD SIGN --

dialogues.speaker: SHOWING OPEN DOORS OF FOUR ROOMETTES
dialogues.text: Through the windows can be seen the landscape through whi the train is passing. In the first roomette, counting fro the left, is a well-dressed, rather wise-looking FEMALE,  young, smart. She is making up her face. In the second is a middle-aged couple, a CANADIAN  IMMIGRATION INSPECTOR and a CANADIAN CUSTOMS INSPECTOR. In the third, BETTY MAYFIELD is seated near the window,  turning over the pages of a magazine. She is about 27 yea old, beautiful, blonde, and has a remote troubled  expression, as though her thoughts were far away. The fourth is empty. There is a man's suitcase in evidenc on the seat. LARRY MITCHELL enters from the left. He is  tall, good-looking, young, with superficial charm and rat too much self-assurance. He glances in at the woman in the first roomette, stops i the door and leans against it. We MOVE IN so this scene becomes a SHOT of a single  roomette. OVER SCENE is HEARD the voices of the Canadian  Immigration Officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good afternoon. You name, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George Olson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the unknown  woman) Better stop while it's still  perfect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks up at him with a slow stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And where were you born, Mr. Olson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waukegan, Illinois.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mitchell) Is there something I can do for  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are a lot of things you could  do for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this is your wife, Mr. Olson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. She was born in Waukegan,  too. Same as Jack Benny, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled) Jack Benny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mitchell) Well, there is something you could  do for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd be delighted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can move to one side. So my  husband can get in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitchell glances back, then moves to one side with a smil He is quite unperturbed. A rather decrepit MAN creeps pas him into the roomette with the unknown WOMAN. She gives  Mitchell a quick flashing smile. Mitchell grins, turns  away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We now see the IMMIGRATION and CUSTOMS OFFICIALS and two  MIDDLE-AGED PASSENGERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Olson) Any firearms? Dutiable articles of  any kind, Mr. Olson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Olson shakes his head. CAMERA PANS Mitchell past this door to the door of better Mayfield's roomette. He leans in this as he did in the  unknown Woman's roomette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Betty) Would you care to see the Seattle  paper?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty turns slowly, stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks, I've seen Seattle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name's Larry Mitchell. I live  in Vancouver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same as an hour ago. Remember?   I'm the steady type.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coldly) I'm afraid there's nothing I can  do about it, Mr. Mitchell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA NOW HAS MOVED IN CLOSE enough to exclude the other roomettes completely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could tell me your name. And  where you're going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How far does this train go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vancouver, B.C.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to Vancouver, Mr.   Mitchell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She picks up a magazine and opens it, ignoring him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O.K. Be rugged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns, starts out, then looks back at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're next for the Immigration  and Customs. I trust your papers  are all in order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty looks up quickly and cannot conceal a startled  expression. Mitchell reacts. CAMERA PULLS BACK as he comes out into corridor, looks  towards the roomette in which the officials are, then tur towards the next roomette and goes into it. Fusses with  his suitcase. CAMERA PANS across to the officials coming out of Olson's roomette. As they come out of Olson's roomette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you will enjoy your stay in  Canada, Mr. Olson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Canadian officials then go on to Betty's roomette, enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your name, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty.. Mayfield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a perceptible hesitation which immigration  officials notices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty Mayfield. Miss or Mrs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitchell is seen in his roomette, standing near the door  listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Mayfield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And where were you born, Miss  Mayfield?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New York, City.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The official is a little suspicious. He looks down at  Betty's hands which are clasped in her lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see you are wearing a wedding  ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been married. My Husband.. (she breaks off and  bites her lip)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I take it Mayfield was not  your married name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is very polite, but is building up to asking for some  identification papers. One this cue, Mitchell comes out o his roomette, crosses, enters Betty's roomette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've wired ahead to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He breaks off, turns to Inspector, recognizes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inspector Gillette, Isn't it? I'm  Larry Mitchell. We've met before,  several times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes out wallet and holds it out to Inspector.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cross the border so often I carry  an identification card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glancing at card) Yes, I remember you, Mr.  Mitchell. (glancing at Betty) You know this lady?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well. Since 1940, at least.   I met her--let me see--it was New  York City, wasn't it Betty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty nods silently. Inspector turns back to her, handing Mitchell's wallet back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Betty) How long do you expect to be in  Canada, Miss Mayfield?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.. a month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (making up his mind) Thank you. I hope you have a  pleasant trip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns away, starts out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Betty) Any firearms? Dutiable articles of  any kind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He marks her baggage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Customs Inspector) My suitcases are open in the next  room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mitchell) Anything dutiable, Mr. Mitchell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Custom Inspector goes out. Mitchell sits down, looks at  Betty coolly. She avoids his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better get rid of the wedding ring.  That's what threw him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty looks out of the window, says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trouble?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty turns her head and looks at him without speaking.  Her face is empty of expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or Reno? (a beat) They always throw them off the  bridge there, I've heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps I don't take it so lightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you staying in Vancouver  Royal. It's pretty crowded you  know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it? I expected to go to the  Vancouver Royal. Should I have a  reservation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll make one for you. (a beat) I live there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doubtfully) Well..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) A very small service. It doesn't  even ask for thanks. How long for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indefinitely?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a shrug) I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyeing her  thoughtfully) You don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and goes. She looks after him, puzzled and rathe attracted. Then his mood passes and she relapses again  into her listless, hopeless manner. She reaches for the  magazine and starts to leaf through its pages indifferent as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a massive brick and sandstone building, set in  beautiful gardens which slope down towards Puget Sound.

dialogues.speaker: THE ENTRANCE
dialogues.text: A taxi drives up, Larry Mitchell and Betty get out, PORTE comes forward, takes their luggage etc. Larry pays taxi  and they start in through entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry and Betty come up to it, BELLHOP carrying luggage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, Mr. Mitchell.   Have a mice trip? Glad to see you  back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, thanks. This is Miss Betty  Mayfield. You have a reservation  for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Mayfield. Yes, indeed. A  balcony room on the top floor,  Magnificent view. Nothing above it  but the penthouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes registration pad towards Betty, and she signs. Mitchell turns, looks out across lobby. A malicious smile move his lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One side of the lobby is a glassed-in-terrace. It is tea  time and a couple of large tea wagons are being pushed  around among the guests by FOOTMEN in uniform. With each  tea wagon are two neat MAIDS, who set out cups, pass  sandwiches, cakes, etc., While the FOOTMAN pours the tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tea wagon beside a table at which sit MR. CLARENDON and MARGO WEST. Mr. Clarendon is elegant, white-haired,  aristocratic-looking, a cane and spats type. Margo is  handsome, thirty-ish, almost overpoweringly well-dressed. Obviously money, obviously been around. Margo is studying her face in a pocket mirror. Tea wagon and maids move awa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm getting positively haggard.   In a couple of years people will  be describing me as well preserved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking off) I see out friend Larry Mitchell is  with us again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margo's hand stops in mid-air, holding mirror. She looks  up slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't care less.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just the same, she sees in which direction. Clarendon is  looking and starts to turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with a very beautiful girl, if  my eyes don't deceive me at this  distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margo reacts and swings around, CAMERA PANNING. Larry and Betty have turned away from the desk and are  going towards elevators, BELLHOP behind them. Larry is  bending towards Betty intimately. Margo turns back to  Clarendon. Her face is frozen with a controlled emotion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I want any tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She picks up her bag and stands up. Goes out of shot.   Clarendon looks after her with a malicious smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Its is very spacious, obviously expensive. It is empty at the moment. Margo unlocks door from outside, comes in,  shuts and cocks door, walks swiftly into room, throws her bag viciously on the desk, yanks her hat off, throws it o chair. She goes over to the balcony window, takes cigaret out of box on the desk, her hand shakes as she lights it  with lighter. She puffs at it furiously, looking out of  window. After a moment, she snubs out in an ashtray, move across to telephone, picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Mr. Larry Mitchell, please (a beat, she changes  her mind) No, never mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts telephone back in cradle and goes back to cigare box, lights another cigarette in the same nervous, jerky  manner, and puffs again. There is a KNOCK ON THE DOOR. Sh spins around, walks quickly to door, throws it open.  Mitchell comes in. She says nothing as he moves in past  her. She shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid you're not very glad to  see me, Margo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (between her teeth) With your charm? How could I help  it? Have a nice trip?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So-so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's the girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her name's Mayfield. Betty Mayfield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's just a girl I met on the  train. You don't mind do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tartly) Why should I mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shouldn't. You washed me up  very thoroughly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As thoroughly as I could. It wasn't  easy. But you are helping me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staring at her) Margo, darling. You washed me up.   Remember? We're just friends. You  wanted it that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring this) She's very beautiful. She's much  younger than I am. And she's rich,  I hope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rich? I haven't the faintest idea.  Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ought to know why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't. My hunch is she's just  torn up an unhappy marriage. I was  able to do her a small favor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Splendid. Now she can return the  compliment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She crosses the desk, gets bag, gets keys out, unlocks th desk drawer and jerks it open, takes something out and  turns, holding it in her hand. Two checks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can give you enough money to  cover these... and the other bad  checks you've given me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitchell comes up to her slowly, looks down at the checks

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hoped to get enough to cover  them before they cleared. I wasn't  lucky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what would happen to you  if I turned these over to the  police?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) I have a rough idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd go to jail. For a long term.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Correct. I couldn't even afford to  pay a lawyer to defend me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat. They stare at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'll we do about it, Margo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is much younger than I am.   That's something I'm going to have  to get used to. Isn't it, Larry?  They'll all be much younger than I  am. Here. (she holds out the  checks) Tear them up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes them, puts them in his pocket and stands there  looking at her. A sob catches in her throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I'm still in love with  you, Larry. What an idiot!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches to take her in his arms. First she pushes him  off, then yields. He pulls her close and kisses her. Then as they come out of the kiss,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've always been a heel. I guess I  always will be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to make a pose of  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the only pose I have left.   I'm sunk. Broke. I don't even have  my hotel bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little sharply) I seem to recognize this routine.   First the kiss then the touch. (she makes a hopeless  gesture.) Oh, what's the use. You're you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns and moves towards the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only have a couple of hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She picks her bag up, holds it out. He comes up beside  her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I seem to remember that you like  to help yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking the bag) That's not very kind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kind or not kind. What's the  difference? It always ends up the  same way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives her a twisted smile, opens the bag, rummages  through it, opens the zipper pocket inside and comes out  with some currency and looks over, puts it in his pocket. Puts the bag down on the desk, glances into the open draw His look becomes fixed. MITCHELL'S POV (what he sees), SHOOTING DOWN INTO THE  DRAWER, is a small, pearl-handled automatic, lying in the corner. Mitchell's hand goes down into it, takes the gun. TWO-SHOT of Margo and Mitchell as his hand comes up with  the gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost amused) What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does it look like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have you had it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Years, why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's against the law to cross the  border with a gun. The Canadian  police might like to know about  this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very quietly) You already have the checks,  darling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean it that way (he puts the gun  back in the drawer,  pushes the drawer  shut.) I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, forget it. Clark Brandon's  throwing a party up in his penthouse  this evening. Take me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about your new friend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a laugh) I told you she's just..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting in sharply) A girl you meet on the train.   Excuse my bringing it up again. (she glances at her  wrist watch) Be back in an hour. Right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In an hour, Larry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitchell stares at her levelly for a moment, then goes  without a word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitchell has just closed the door, stands with his hand o the knob, a smile playing across his features. He starts  to whistle as he walks down the corridor. He takes a litt dance step perhaps, this is to indicate that his whole  attitude with Margo is just part of an act. He stops besi the big sand jar, lights a cigarette, drops the match in  the jar, takes out the money from Margo's bag, flips it  with a smile on his face, puts it back in his pocket, tak out the two checks Margo gave him, tears off the signatur places checks in his pocket, tears the signature fragment into small pieces, drops them into the jar, goes on  whistling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple of GUESTS at the desk. A CLERK is handing out  mail. CAMPBELL, the manager, is standing to one side. The elevator comes down. Mitchell comes out, crosses to the  desk and addresses Campbell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, Mr. Campbell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coldly) Mr. Mitchell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (airily) A little something on account  perhaps?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rather more than a little something,  Mr. Mitchell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid this is all for the  moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell picks up the money, counts it, puts it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we'd better discuss this  in my office, Mr. Mitchell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing to discuss. Tomorrow the  sun will shine even brighter. Be  grateful for small mercies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell shrugs, reaches for the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I forgot. I have a dinner  engagement. Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He removes a couple of bills from the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. Campbell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts money in his pocket, turns away. Campbell looks  after him with cold anger. Mitchell dodges back into  elevator just as it is about to start up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hat and suitcase in sight. Light is on in the closet. Bet is inside closet, hanging up clothes. As she comes out,  switching off light, DOOR BUZZER SOUNDS. She opens door,  Mitchell breezes on past her. She registers annoyance,  then closes door. Mitchell crosses to the open French doo of the balcony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice room. Balcony and everything.  Lovely view too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coolly) Very nice Mitchell turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (same voice) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frowning) Suppose I hadn't known that  immigration inspector? Hadn't put  in a good word for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm supposing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're a nice girl. I like  you. But I can read signs if the  print is large enough. It was your  manner more than the wedding ring  that bothered the inspector.  A  sort of tenseness, as if you were  afraid of something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty just goes on looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a darned good idea you're  name isn't Betty Mayfield at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about taking to Uncle Larry  into the old firm? He's a useful  guy to have on your side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (no answer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slight change of  pace) Don't get me wrong, Betty. I'm not  suggesting you murdered anybody,  you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty reacts. He sees the reaction. His smile broadens.   Then very casually,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dine and dance tonight? I've got  fifty bucks to throw away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not in the mood for dining and  dancing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have some nice places around  Vancouver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure you have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled a little) Well, how about a breeze up to the  penthouse about six o'clock?  A  friend of mine is throwing a  cocktail party up there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't been invited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody gets invited to Clark  Brandon's parties. They just go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps I'd better get you  straightened out, Mr. Mitchell.   You've been rather nice to me, in  a couple of ways. And I'm grateful.  But I don't think this entitles  you to put me on a leash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody I'd rather have on a leash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty crosses to the door and opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm awfully sorry, but I'd like to  take a bath and get freshened up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitchell hesitates, then comes across slowly to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brush-off, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying very hard to be polite  about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitchell grins, then suddenly reaches for her and kisses  her. She doesn't struggle, is quite impassive. After a  moment he let's go, steps back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't I even get my face slapped?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating the  open door) Would you mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little puzzled,  confused by her  attitude) Okay. You win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you change your mind about the  cocktail party, or anything else,  give me a buzz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I change my mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes. He closes the door. CAMERA MOVES IN ON HER FACE. She wipes off her lips with her handkerchief, almost in a absentminded way. The kiss didn't mean anything to her,  one way or another. There is great loneliness in her eyes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Showing a lot of activity, etc. The time is 6:00 P.M. Approximately, but this is June in  Canada and broad daylight, and will be for several hours  yet. In the background Betty comes in through glass doors from the garden terrace, walks slowly across the lobby.  Peopl are looking at her with interest, specially the men.  As  she reaches the elevator bank, she glances off to one sid past the desk. Her look becomes fixed. CAMERA PANS AROUND TO SHOW A NEON SIGN "TAVERN" this side of an archway and people going in. She turns away from elevator, starts in that direction,  passes on beneath sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Betty come in, stands looking around. It is lighted  somewhat dimly. There are a number of small tables,. Ther is a bar but it is only for the use of the waiters. Betty looks around for a vacant table, then starts moving along looking for one. None empty, but at one sits a MAN alone. He is about 35, clean fine drawn type, with a saturnine  expression. He glances up. Betty meets his eyes, starts t turn away. Man indicates the chair opposite him. His mann of doing this is so completely indifferent to her as a  person, that she hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing up) You can have the table yourself,  if you'd rather. I'm only killing  time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down then. We often have a  double up here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pulls the chair back, sits down. Brandon sits down. H lights a cigarette, doesn't offer her one. She is watchin him, a little puzzled, probably has had very few experien of men not trying to pick her up in such circumstances.  Betty looks around at the scurrying WAITERS who pay no  attention to her yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out sharply) Oh waiter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WAITER turns, sees him, immediately comes to stand at his side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon, without speaking, indicates Betty. Waiter turns  to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like a dry Martini. Very dry,  please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Miss. Beer and ale only.   Canadian law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised) Beer? (she shrugs) Well, all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beer or ale, Miss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ale. I don't mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns away. Brandon is smiling at her faintly, She mee his eyes, smiles back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Brandon) Your liquor laws..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting in) Disgusting, aren't they? If you  really want a Martini, I know where  you can get one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty looks inquiringly at him and doesn't speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fellow named Brandon has a  penthouse here. He's holding open  house. I was up there. Too noisy.   Bored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indifferently) It might be worth a Martini to  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need it that badly. I don't  enjoy crashing other people's  parties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's open-house. No crashing  involved. Anybody in the hotel's  welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you say his name was?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon. Clark Brandon. Fellow  about my age. Lot of money... that  he didn't make. Former American.  Now naturalized in Canada. Social  standing indeterminate. Manners  not quite perfect. Scotch superb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't sound as if you liked  him very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) No.. not very well. And I like his  friends even less. But.. (he waves his hand  indifferently) If you really want a good dry  Martini..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As I said before...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. But I'd hate like the Dickens  to be held to everything I've said  before, wouldn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty suddenly laughs. The waiter brings the glass and th bottle of bass ale, sets them down in front of her. Brand makes a motion and the waiter goes away without collectin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not paying for this. It's  quite enough that you let me sit  at your table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never pay for anything. They  just keep me here to amuse the  guests.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And do you amuse the guests?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. (indicating her  bottle of ale) Are you really going to drink that  stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're drinking it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating his  almost untouched  glass) I can be talked out of it. As a  matter of fact, I'd like a dry  Martini myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would it make you anymore amusing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever you say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing up and  putting money on  the table) I don't know you and you don't  know me. I made a reasonably polite  suggestion. But I'm sure you'd  rather be alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate to be alone. But I've heard  all the approaches there are...  even yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon turns back, stares down at her coldly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neatly said...but to the wrong  man. The trouble with pretty girls  is that they can't imagine anyone  thinking of anything else but the  fact they are pretty girls. I get  tired of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (directly) Do you think I don't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interested) Thanks for the fresh air. That  felt good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing up and  taking her bag) You're sure Mr. Brandon won't mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't even know half the people  who come up to drink his liquor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An elevator comes up. Brandon and Betty come out. There i a sound of revelry behind the penthouse door, opposite th elevators. They cross. Brandon opens the door casually,  without bothering to ring, users Betty in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big room, with French doors opening on a large terrace. A few couples are dancing outside on the terrace and a fe more inside the room. There is a portable bar at one side of the room and two WAITERS behind it. The dance music is coming from a large Radio-Phonograph. Brandon and Betty  come in. Brandon shuts the door. There are eighteen or  twenty people around, with the usual alcoholic glitter in their eyes and the usual strident voices and exaggerated  laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DISCOVERING Mitchell leaning against it, staring morosely into a drink. He drains the last of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to bartender in a  thick voice) Another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BARTENDER takes a glass. Brandon and Betty come up to the bar. Mitchell does not at first look up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to bartender) This lady would like a dry Martini.  So would I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns away. Mitchell looks up, sees Betty, reacts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well well. Baby wouldn't come with  me. Where did you pick her up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon glances from Betty to Mitchell puzzled, shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mitchell. Having fun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The liquors lovely. The rest of  the party you can have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves towards Betty, puts an arm around her. Betty ris tries to pull away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter, baby. Don't you  like me anymore?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mitchell) Lay off, can't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lay off what? This is my new girl  friend. Met her on the train.   She's very fond of me. Love at  first sight. Wasn't it, baby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon reacts. There is a certain contempt in his look a Betty now. Bartender serves drinks impassively. Mitchell  grabs his, gulps half of it down. Betty quietly releases  herself and moves away from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'd begun to think this was my  lucky day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A liveried HOTEL SERVANT COMES INTO SHOT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Brandon) You're wanted on the telephone,  Mr. Brandon. Mrs. West.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Servant says "Brandon", Betty reacts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to servant) Thanks. (to Betty with brutal  sarcasm) If you are a friend of Larry  Mitchell's I'm sure I leave you in  good hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes out of SHOT. She looks after him unhappily. CAMERA PANS BRANDON across his living room to an inner  door.  He starts through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Telephone on table, receiver down as Brandon enters, clos door against the noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello Margo. Aren't you coming up? (a beat) Mitchell? Oh yes, he's here. (he smiles a little  grimly) He came up alone, but it seems he  has a new girl friend with him  now. (a beat) Don't be theatrical, Margo. What  do you care about Mitchell? Come  on up and have a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margo on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a flat voice) I haven't any intensions of being  theatrical. Of course I'll come  up. Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up, stand for a moment, staring at nothing, the she turns, picks her wrap out of the chair, puts it on,  crosses to the desk for her handbag. She opens the bag,  pauses, then in SLOW MOTION, pulls open the drawer of the desk. CAMERA IN CLOSE, studies her face as she looks down into  the drawer of the desk, which we do not see. But we alrea know there is a gun there. Her body is quite motionless,  her expression frozen. When she moves we do not see wheth she takes the gun out of the drawer or not.  We HEAR the  SNAP of her bag shutting. The she turns away, starts acro the room to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A quiet, gentlemanly-looking MAN is leaning against the  back wall of the elevator, wearing a trench coat and a  soft hat. He is a homicide dick named KILLAINE, but you'd never think that to look at him. Elevator stops, doors  open, and Margo enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very polite) Did you have a nice day, Mrs.   West?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a rotten day, if its any of  your business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm terribly sorry, Mrs. West.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't let it break you up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I wouldn't do that, Mrs.  West.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man chuckles, Margo looks around at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's so funny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine wipes the smile off his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (imitating boy) I'm terribly sorry, Mrs. West.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she stares at him, he takes his monocle out of his  pocket, polishes it, sticks it in his eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, the Coldstream Guards. (a beat) Don't you take your hat off in  elevators?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleasantly) I never wear a hat. (his face changes  to consternation) Oh, so I am. I forgot. (he takes his hat  off) I guess I'm terribly sorry again,  Mrs. West.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elevator stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Penthouse floor, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margo sweeps out, Killaine follows her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they cross to the Penthouse door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes the button.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May you what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you always this witty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine laughs as the door opens. Brandon stands in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Margo. Hello Killaine. You two  come together?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the same elevator. It is a public  conveyance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA TAKES THEM INTO THE ROOM the door starts to close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon, Killaine and Margo standing by the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me introduce you. Mr.  Killaine,  Mrs. West.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not looking at  Killaine) Fascinated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her eyes roam the room. She picks out Mitchell. Her  expression freezes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHAT SHE SEES -- Betty is sitting in her chair in a corne and Mitchell is standing over her, his hand on the back o the chair. Her expression is wooden. His is a mixture of  insolence and pleading. CAMERA RETURNS TO MARGO, BRANDON AND KILLAINE as they cro to the bar. At the same time Mitchell leaves Betty, also crosses to  the bar, reaches it about the same time as Margo. Margo  gives Mitchell a long, cool, empty stare. Mitchell smiles a little sheepishly, embarrassed even in his drunkenness. At the same time Mitchell leaves Betty, also crosses to  the bar, reaches it about the same time as Margo. Margo  gives Mitchell a long, cool, empty stare. Mitchell smiles a little sheepishly, embarrassed even in his drunkenness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'll you have, Margo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without looking at  him) Martini.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Killaine) You, Killaine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scotch and plain water, I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not looking at him) Warm water, no doubt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A private joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets the monocle out and sticks it in his eye again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It goes with this... cold houses  and warm drinks...the effete  Englishman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bartender serves drinks. Margo puts her bag down on the  bar. It makes a heavy CLUNKING SOUND. KILLAINE'S eyes go  to it, without too much expression. Mitchell reacts more. To him the clunking sound has a meaning. He starts to rea for the bag. Margo pointedly moves it away from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Margo thickly) I'm sorry. I forgot about calling  for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's quite unimportant, Mr.   Mitchell. After all, you got what  you wanted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be nasty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no intension of being nasty,  Mr. Mitchell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In that case, there's someone here  I'd like to introduce to you. Over  there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margo looks towards Betty. She reacts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost to herself) She is beautiful. And young. (she turns back to  Mitchell) No thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aggressively) I say YES!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margo quietly turning her back on him and reaching for he glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not the type to be masterful,  darling. It takes character.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitchell reaches for her shoulder and spins her around,  causing her to slop some of her drink out on the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with sudden deadly  sweetness) Of course, darling. Anything you  say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes off with Mitchell. Killaine looks after then  puzzled. Brandon is indifferent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I like about cocktail  parties. Everyone is so perfectly  natural.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's life treating you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The usual grind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Round of golf Saturday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I can get off.

dialogues.speaker: CORNER OF THE ROOM
dialogues.text: Betty is sitting alone as Margo and Mitchell COME INTO  SHOT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty, this is Margo West. She  wants to meet you. Miss Mayfield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staring at her) You're very attractive, my dear.   And you look very unsophisticated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unsophisticated? (he laughs nastily) If I knew about this babe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty stands up quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'd like to dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why certainly, baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts his arm around Betty and dances off with her,  leaving Margo standing. CAMERA FOLLOWS THEM as they dance. They pass Mr. Clarendon, who is sitting as usual with his sliver-haired cane between his legs, paying no particular attention to anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mitchell as  they dance) Please be a little more careful  how you talk, Mr. Mitchell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How careful should I be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like being referred to as  babe, or addressed as baby. I don't  like your possessive attitude, nor  your hints of secret knowledge. In  fact, to be very frank, Mr.  Mitchell, I don't think I like  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you're going to have to like  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He disengages her left hand enough to hold it up and look at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've shed the ring, haven't you?  Took my advice. That's the girl.  Keep right on taking my advice and  we'll get somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty jerks away from him and stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just drunk enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts his arm around her, pulls her close to him, and  tilts her head back. She struggles against him, silently. He pushes her head back father and kisses her solidly on  the mouth. She finally breaks away from him with flashing eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter, baby? Don't you  like being kissed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with cold fury) Next time you try that, Mr.   Mitchell... (a beat, she takes  a deep breath,  then very pointedly) ..don't. I'm warning you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do me a favor, Mitchell. Find  yourself a nice secluded park bench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (airily) Did I do something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't know. Just do it  somewhere else. There is such a  thing as good manners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How would you know, Brandon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (harshly) Want to walk out... or get thrown  out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't throw guests out, Brandon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't bet on it. I'm eccentric.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men glare at each other. Mitchell finally shrugs  then goes towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Brandon, quietly) It takes two to clinch.  Clark.   Nice to have seen you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts towards the door. Brandon hurries quickly to  open it for her. She goes without looking at him, her mou tight. He shuts the door, looks back towards Betty, who  has remained standing perfectly still. She takes a  handkerchief out of her bag and scrubs her mouth off as  Brandon comes back to her. Clarendon stands up slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Betty, offhand) Dance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Brandon) Where I come from, Mr. Brandon,  the host tries to protect his guests  from insult.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I stopped him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if he fails, he at least has  the good manners to apologize.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't exactly regard Larry  Mitchell's pick-ups...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarendon turns back on him. Then--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Betty, with  courtly gesture) We haven't been introduced. But if  you'll overlook that, I'm sure  that between us we can contrive a  graceful exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling at him  warmly) Thank you very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They go towards the door side by side. Brandon turns and CAMERA PANS HIM BACK TO BAR where Killa has remained motionless, his drink untasted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would it have helped if I'd knocked  him down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hardly. Who's the girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody Mitchell picked up on the  train. I don't even know her name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't look like a girl who  would let herself be picked up on  a train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I thought, at first. (a beat) Maybe somebody else ought to have  thrown this party. (a beat) With my liquor of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Face of traveling clock on a night table. Room is dark,  lit only by moonlight. Hands of the clock stand almost  11:15. Ticking is HEARD faintly. A little smoke drifts  across the face of the clock. CAMERA PANS BACK ALONG THE SMOKE to Betty lying in bed,  her eyes wide open. Somewhere outside a CHURCH CLOCK CHIM the quarter hour. The last strokes of the clock are drown out by a sudden peal of THUNDER. Betty jerks upright in  bed.  The thunder frightens her. There is another LOUDER  peal, this time preceded by a FLASH of LIGHTENING which  LIGHTS UP HER FACE. She shuts her eyes against it. The  THUNDERSTORM grows suddenly HEAVY. Repeated FLASHES of  LIGHTENING across her FACE and peals of THUNDER. CAMERA MOVES IN ON HER EYES which are frozen.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA PULLS BACK VERY SLOWLY
dialogues.text: And everything has changed except Betty's expression. The FLASHES go on, but they are now seen to be FLASHBULBS of  NEWSPAPER CAMERAMEN. Betty is dressed very soberly and is standing just inside the door of a courtroom with a jail  matron beside her. The CAMERA KEEPS PULLING BACK AWAY FROM BETTY, and the  entire courtroom is seen. It is late at night in the county courthouse GREENWATER,  NORTH CAROLINA. There is an excited buzzing of conversati A BAILIFF is RAPPING for order. The JURY is sitting, grim faced and silent, in the box.  The Judge is not on the bench yet. Betty is led along the side corridor then through the bar where DEFENSE ATTORNEY, a haggard, dark-haired young man, stands waiting for her. (NOTE: All Southern accents except Betty's in this scene)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) Everybody stand up! His Honor,  Judge Hopkinson! Court now in  session!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody stands up. Betty and the jail matron and the  young attorney face towards the bench. CAMERA SHOWS THE PROSECUTING ATTORNEY, also standing up a his table. CAMERA PANS OVER TO THE DOOR OF THE JUDGES CHAMBERS. He  walks slowly to the bench, stands for a moment behind it, looking out over the courtroom, then sits down. He is a  distinguished courtly Southerner of the best type, an old man but very erect. When he sits, all the spectators and  lawyers sit down. The double doors at the back are closed and a BAILIFF sta with his back to them. Suddenly, one of the doors is push open, almost knocking the Bailiff out of the way. He turns angrily as HENRY KINSOLVING enters. The Bailiff  seeing who it is, stands aside. Henry Kinsolving is an  arrogant, bitter man about 60 years old, with the stamp o power and authority. He marches down the center aisle of  the court through the bar, and sits at the table near the PROSECUTOR. The Judge stares down at him coldly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Bailiff, please make room for  Mr. Henry Kinsolving, outside the  bar of the court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry Kinsolving springs to his feet and glares at the  Judge. Then he turns and goes through the gate of the bar and sits down outside in a chair the Bailiff places for  him solicitously. There is a general shuffling of feet an noise which subsides slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly and  impressively) Before the Jury renders its verdict,  the Court wishes to warn those  present that there is to be no  demonstrations of any kind. No  person is to leave the courtroom  until the Court rises. (he glances towards  press table) I repeat... no one is to leave the  courtroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a silence, then the Judge turns towards the Cler

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may proceed, Mr. Clerk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he stands and looks  at Elizabeth) The Defendant will rise and face  the Jury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELIZABETH stands up slowly and turns towards the Jury, wh do not look at her. They stare somewhere over her head.  The Clerk turns back to the Jury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen of the Jury, have you  reached a verdict?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing) We have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what is your verdict?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We the Jury, find the Defendant,  Elizabeth Kinsolving, guilty of  murder in the first degree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a surge of noise in the well of the court. The  Judge raps sharply with his gavel. A couple of PRESSMEN  start to get up, then look back and see that the doors ar guarded and sit down again. The Prosecutor looks grimly  satisfied; he glances at the DEFENDING COUNCIL with a hal smile. Defense Counsel, whose name is LEAMINGTON, is shoc and pale. Elizabeth shows no reaction at all. Henry  Kinsolving draws his mouth a little tighter, and there is a gleam in his eye. The Spectators look, for the most par very satisfied. Leamington comes to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a strangled  voice) Motion to pool the Jury, if it  please the Court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So ordered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Clerk now proceeds to poll the Jury, saying "Juror No 1 what is your verdict?" And the Juror answering "Guilty  of murder in the first degree." "Juror No. 2, what is you verdict?" Etc. This is covered by a series of CLOSE UPS  all answer clearly until the Clerk comes to Juror No. 7,  who mumbles in a low voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Juror No. 7) Speak a little louder please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juror No. 7 is staring hard at Elizabeth. His face is  twisted with emotion. He is the only Juror who has looked at her. He swallows, doesn't answer, then his eyes go to  Henry Kinsolving. Henry Kinsolving glares at Juror No. 7. Juror No. 7 wilts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thickly and  hesitatingly) Guilty of murder in the first  degree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Clerk completes the polling of the Jury, then turns t the Judge. The Judge nods and Clerk sits down. The courtr starts to get noisy again, and the Judge uses his gavel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Order in the Court!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Court now has a statement to  make.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances towards Elizabeth, who is still standing rigid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently) Please sit down, Mrs. Kinsolving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth sits, and clasps her hands in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This court, like most courts, has  occasionally been guilty of judicial  error. Prior to the commencement  of this trail, Mr.  Leamington, as  attorney for the Defendant, made a  motion for a change of venue on  the ground that a fair trial could  not be had by this Defendant in  this jurisdiction. Most of you  know why this motion was made.   The Defendant was alleged to have  been tried and convicted in the  columns of the daily newspaper  owned by her father-in-law, Mr.   Henry Kinsolving, and as a result  public opinion was said to have  been prejudiced to the extent that  it was doubtful twelve Jurors could  be found with open minds. This  Court regretfully denied the motion.  It did not believe that a Jury  with open minds could not be found.  The members of this Jury declared  on oath that their minds were open.   The Court had no reason at that  time to disbelieve them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge looks at the Jury sternly, and they react in  various ways. The Judge's eyes go to Henry Kinsolving, wh stares back at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth Kinsolving has been tried  and found guilty of murder of her  husband, Lee Kinsolving.  Lee  Kinsolving was the only son of our  most prominent citizen.  Mr.  Kinsolving controls, or is said to  control, our leading bank, many of  our business enterprises and our  only daily newspaper. He affords  employment to a large number of  our citizens. His influence on our  affairs is very great. (dramatic pause) Perhaps to great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is an upsurge of noise in the Court and the Bailiff shots for order. Prosecutor jumps to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Honor, I protest that  statement!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down, Mr. Prosecutor. Your are  out of order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prosecutor swallows, looks back at Henry Kinsloving, shru and sits down again. Leamington is leaning forward with a gleam in his eye. Elizabeth is still deadpan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all new Lee Kinsolving well, We  watched him grow up.  We observed  that he was proud and hot tempered,  and had a strain of arrogance, not  unlike others of his family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks meaningfully at Henry Kinsolving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From this town Lee Kinsolving went  to fight for his country.  And to  this town, before he went overseas,  he brought the wife he had married  up North. To us he returned a war  hero badly wounded, condemned for  the rest of his life to wear a  heavy brace around his neck.  Competent medical testimony has  shown that without that brace a  very slight movement might have  been enough to snap his spinal  cord. This injury humiliated and  embittered Lee Kinsolving, made  him morose and violent, and perhaps  caused him to drink to excess. The  Defendant has admitted that there  were bitter quarrels between herself  and her husband. Such a quarrel  took place on the night of his  death, Upon the manner of that  death this entire proceeding rests.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge pauses and looks out over the courtroom, which  is very quiet now, He pours himself a glass of water and  takes a drink from it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In my summing up to the Jury I  emphasized that the case for the  prosecution was, as so many murder  cases are, purely circumstantial.  It was alleged that while Lee  Kinsolving slept, perhaps in a  drunken stupor and perhaps not,  the Defendant removed the neck  brace from his neck and jerked his  head sufficiently to rupture the  spinal cord and cause death. It is  admitted that the Defendant was  found holding the neck brace in  her hand, and bending over her  husband's body, which was lying on  the bed. Not in the bed, mind you,  but sprawled across it.  The  Defendant has testified that lee  Kinsolving himself removed the  neck brace to torment her, as it  were, with the great danger in  which this placed him. Then he  started to walk towards her, holding  the brace in his hands, and that  being unsteady on his feet, he  stumbled and fell backwards across  the bed. And this fall broke his  neck, although at the time she did  not know it. She has testified  that she picked the brace up from  the floor and was about to attempt  to replace it on his neck when her  father-in-law entered the room and  found her in that position. (a beat) By its verdict the Jury declared  that Elizabeth Kinsolving's account  of the death of her husband to be  impossible of belief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge sips a little more water, then continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In all murder trails, a motion by  the Defense for a directed verdict  of acquittal before the case goes  to the Jury is more or less  automatic. It is usually  perfunctory, and for that reason  immediately denied. The laws of  this state, and a few other  jurisdictions, confer upon a Court  a right to reserve its ruling upon  such a motion until after the Jury  has rendered its verdict. In this  proceeding, I, as presiding Judge,  availed myself of this power. I  most honestly hoped that the Jury  in this case might act as  impartially as it declared itself  to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Prosecuting Attorney again jumps to his feet, then  changes his mind, sits down with a frustrated angry  movement. Kinsolving is leaning forward, glaring. The Jur are now very uncomfortable. The is a BUZZ OF NOISE and th Bailiff again shouts for order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me remind you that a Jury is  the sole Judge of fact, and further  let me remind you that the Jury  must judge all the facts. It may  not select nor create nor change  facts. It may only interpret them.  It may not declare something  impossible which in fact is merely  extremely difficult to believe. (a beat) Impossible is a very big word. (another beat.) If we believe Elizabeth Kinsolving's  sworn testimony, we must also  believe that Lee Kinsolving  performed an act which was almost  certain to cause his death. It is  difficult... very difficult to  believe. But is it impossible? Are  we sure that he knew it would cause  his death? Or that in his then  state of mind, he even considered  the consequences at all? Many people  have attempted suicide as a result  of domestic quarrels. Not all have  succeeded, nor meant to succeed.  And surely not all those who did  succeed... fully intended to. Not  all knew what they were doing and  those who did know, there were  surely a few whose desire to hurt  others overcame their fear of  hurting themselves.  We cannot  know what was in Lee Kinsolving's  Mind. Therefore, some element of  doubt must infallibly remain. It  was not necessary for this Jury to  declare its belief in the  Defendant's innocence, nor to  declare its that Lee Kinsolving by  accident or his own intent. It was  necessary for the Jury to admit to  themselves, as reasonable men, the  possibility.... however slight...  that Elizabeth Kinsolving's story  was true. This possibility the  Jury has refused to admit. (dramatic pause) It therefore becomes my duty to  declare that such a possibility  does in fact exist... and the Jury's  refusal to recognize it was a  failure to exercise it proper  function.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A rising, antagonistic sound begins to surge from the  spectators and Henry Kinsolving comes to his feet, slowly and rigidly. The Judge ignore him and looks straight at  the foreman of the Jury, and speaks the rest of his speec in a clear, ringing, dominating voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Court therefore rules that the  motion of the Attorney for the  Defense for a directed verdict of  not guilty be now granted. The  verdict of guilty brought by this  Jury is herby set aside, and a  verdict of not guilty is to be  entered on the record. (his voice bow rises  almost to a shout) And the Defendant, Elizabeth  Kinsolving, is here with discharged  from custody of the Sheriff of  this county.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PANDEMONIUM and UPROAR in the Court. The Bailiff shouts  for order. The Judge stands slowly, looks a moment out  over the Court, then looks at Elizabeth, smiles at her  faintly, turns, and starts back towards his chambers. CAMERA PANS over to Henry Kinsolving. He stands like a  statue, an icy rage, his face working, while behind him  the noise of the spectators goes on. Kinsolving turns his head towards Elizabeth, then moves stiffly over to her. CAMERA PANNING, he comes over to her. Leamington, the  Defense Attorney, and the matron are standing beside her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with restrained  fury) For four years I endured your  presence in my house, although I  well knew you were no fit wife for  my son.. That he had married in  haste, and that he would repent it  bitterly if he survived the war. I  had no thought that he would die  under his own roof, nor that the  reward of my patience would be to  stand beside his grave. I have  done my best to avenge him. So far  I have failed.  But I have not  finished. You are free to go where  you will, but there will be another  day of reckoning, somewhere,  sometime.  And when that day comes,  I will be there. And that time you  will not escape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth's eyes widen with horror. In the background the crowd is still roaring, like peals of thunder. CAMERA MOVES IN CLOSE TO ELIZABETH'S EYES as at the  beginning of this flashback.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA WITHDRAWS and find her sitting up in bed in the  ROYAL HOTEL. THUNDER is pealing outside, but now more  distantly. There is a sudden downpour of RAIN. Betty swee the bedclothes aside. Reaches for a robe, and crosses to  close the French doors. Over her shoulder we see a portio of the small balcony, a chaise, and as Betty starts to  close the door, she stops frozen. There is someone lying  on the chaise. She starts out into the rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she comes out, approaches the chaise, leans down, the  rain beating on her. She shakes the shoulder of a man on  the chaise. He doesn't move. One of his hands drops limpl and swings a little. Horror shows in Betty's eyes. She  reaches out and touches the man's face and WE SEE for the first time that this is Larry Mitchell, and we realize  that he is dead.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: The NIGHT PORTER is seated at his desk, reading a paper.  He is a middle-aged man in uniform and military bearing,  with a row or ribbons across his chest. Probably, in orde of seniority, a Military Medal, a Good Conduct Medal, the Long Service Medal, and two or three campaign ribbons.  Betty, now fully dressed, COMES SLOWLY INTO THE SHOT and  stops by his desk. Porter lays down his paper and stands  up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How soon can I get a plane to  Seattle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid there's nothing more  tonight, Miss. Unless you charter  a plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long would that take?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... they have to service the  plane... and get a pilot down to  the field, unless there's one  hanging around there still... and  then they have to get the  immigration officer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Immigration Officer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crossing the border this time of  night they're a bit particular.   You'd have to prove your identity,  you know... unless you've got a  passport. They might even want to  know why you're in such a hurry. (he grins) Otherwise they might think...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He breaks off, staring at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They might think I was running  away from something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Possibly, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns and exits. CAMERA FOLLOWS HER ALONG. She turns  the corner by the elevator bank, starts into the elevator Brandon is standing there in a light overcoat, with his  hat in his hand. She get's in without noticing him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leaving us so soon, Miss Mayfield?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She realizes his presence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't blame you.. For running  away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty reacts sharply, controls herself, says nothing.   Elevator stops, doors open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts out. Brandon after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't the penthouse floor,  Mr. Brandon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon keeps going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty is walking quickly down the corridor towards her  room. Brandon is following her. She seems unaware of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) Miss Mayfield...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty stops turns, and he comes up to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it's a littler late for an  apology.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a strained, un  natural voice) Much too late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't take it so big... it isn't a  tragedy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty goes into a peal of hysterical laughter, Brandon  grabs hold of her arm and shakes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty stops laughing just as suddenly as she began.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said it wasn't a tragedy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's funny about that? If you  pick up people like Larry Mitchell  other people are bound to get funny  ideas about you. The world is full  of Larry Mitchells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's one less tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon reacts. Silently she holds out a key. He takes it It's a tabbed hotel room key.

dialogues.speaker: DOOR OPENS
dialogues.text: Brandon comes in, stands aside as Betty comes in. He shut and locks the door. The room is lighted up. Brandon looks around swiftly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out on the balcony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS Brandon across the room to the balcony door,  he steps out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon enters. He goes quickly to chaise, stares down,  bends, appears to pick something up. What is it not seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty is standing motionless in the middle of the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the heart, apparently.   Very little blood. What's the story?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty looks him straight in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There isn't one.. That anyone would  believe. I went for a walk after  dinner, down to the ocean...alone...  I came up and went to bed. I didn't  sleep very well. Then there was a  thunderstorm. And it began to rain.   I went across to close the French  door. That's the first time I saw  him out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He got in here how?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not with my consent, strange as it  seems. I don't know how he got in.  I don't know anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon brings his hand up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever see this before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty looks down. In his hand is an automatic with a pear handle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. And I've never fired a gun in  my life, Aren't you supposed not  to touch it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure... but somebody always does..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts the gun down on the table carelessly, gets out a  cigarette case and offers her one. She takes it and he  lights it for her. Her hand is shaky. Their faces are ver close together. He holds the lighter close to her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Lovely eyes... honest eyes..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The light goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll know whether he killed  himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you meet him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a train. He said he lived here,  and he offered to make a reservation  for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knew the immigration officer.   He eased himself in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a great boy for that. What  else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all there is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon takes her by the shoulders and pulls her close,  looking into her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're still honest eyes... but  there's something behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls her closer, about to kiss her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead...if you want to. It  doesn't matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd rather wait until it does  matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lets go of her and starts across the room, picks up  telephone. Brandon turns with the telephone in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tried to run away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There wasn't any plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's always a mistake to run away.  Always.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He begins to dial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon is standing at the French window, a cup of coffee in his hand. CAMERA PULLS BACK AS his eyes go over to Bet who is in a chair with an untouched cup of black coffee o the table beside her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going towards her) Want a spike in it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without looking at  him) No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her voice and expression are dead and exhausted. CAMERA  PULLS BACK FURTHER to SHOW Margo and Clarendon sitting  across the room from Betty. Margo is staring at Betty wit cold hostility. She is wearing slacks, but otherwise dres with care and finish. Clarendon is fully dressed and has  his silver-topped cane between his legs, but has slippers on his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You make friends quickly, don't  you, Clark?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And without much discrimination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave that one lay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They still hang women in Canada,  I've heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So much less refined than frizzling  them in the chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, shut up! (she looks down at  his feet) You haven't even got your spats  on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon crosses to coffee table, picks up coffee pot and  goes to Margo with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think I'll have trouble staying  awake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon fills her cup silently. Margo chokes. Bites on he handkerchief hard. She controls herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. This thing has just  knocked me silly.  How long do we  have to wait for this police  character?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until he comes. He's a nice guy.   You've met him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That comedian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty looking across at Brandon with sudden interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't let the eyeglass fool you.   That's what it's for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOOR BUZZER SOUNDS. Brandon crosses to open door. A plain clothes Dick named HANDLEY is standing there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You Mr. Brandon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inspector Killaine's compliments.   He'll be up in another ten minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon nods again, and as Handley starts to turn away,  Brandon starts to close the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Portable lights have been rigged up and a POLICE  PHOTOGRAPHER is taking photographs of the body. As he  finishes, a sheet is thrown over it and the photographer  starts to dismantle his equipment and pack it up.
