A coupl of PLAIN-CLOTHES MEN are standing around, and one of them named GORE, a detective sergeant, a big sore-head who  doesn't like anybody. As the photographer extinguishes on of the lights and starts to wind up the cord, Gore looks  off and scowls. Killiane ENTERS SHOT briskly. He is wearing a trenchcoat  and no hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You in charge here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it seems Sergeant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate to pull rank on you Sergeant,  but once in a while...for moral  purposes...you might address me as  "Inspector". In moments of extreme  desperation, you might even call  me "sir".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes over to the chaise, lifts the sheet off corpse,  looks down, replaces sheet, comes back to Gore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew him. He was easy to dislike,  poor chap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They tell me he'll be a great loss  to the liquor trade. This Mayfield  girl...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He breaks off as Killaine reacts

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I supposed you knew her, too,  Inspector.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've met her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's her room. She only got to the  Hotel this afternoon,. With him. (he indicates body  on chaise) I guess he took too much for  granted. Here's the gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes it out of his pocket and holds it out on a  handkerchief. Killaine takes the gun from him, handkerchi and all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pearl-handled .25 Automatic, uh? (he looks a little  closer) No, it's a Belgian gun... 6.6 mm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Correct, Inspector. A woman's gun.  U.S. 125 caliber ammunition in it.  It was on a table in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods towards room. Killaine frowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody's been questioned yet. You  noticed the wound entry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much too low for a suicide. Not  conclusive, of course. But a woman  of ordinary height, standing rather  close to a tall man, such as he  was... (indicating corpse) ...would be apt to shoot him about  where he got shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine nods again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then there's the shell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes out a small envelope, hands it to Killaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This make of gun throws a shell  backwards, high, and to the right.  The chaise is only about four feet  from the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So the shell ought to have gone  over?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unless the gun was slanted up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So the wound and the shell give  you the same answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. A clean deduction from  observed facts. They've got to be  simple once in a while, Inspector.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dryly) I've always looked forward to it.   All right, let's get him out of  here and tidy up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to turn away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd take a look in her clothes  closet if I were you, Inspector.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine nods and exits scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine enters from the balcony then stands a moment,  looking around, crosses to dressing table, looks down, an we SEE traces of fingerprint powder on the toilet article and bottles. He doesn't touch anything. He crosses to  closet, opens door. A light goes on inside. He starts in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine examines several garments, takes a sports coat  off hanger, opens it up at lining. His looks becomes fixe and intent. He reacts. (What he sees is that the sewed-in label has been removed from the garment.) Slowly he repla the coat, then takes down another garment, goes through  the same performance. He whistles very softly between his teeth, stands a moment with a puzzled expression on his  face, replaces the garment. Exits closet. Light goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As elevator come up, Killaine exits elevator, crosses,  presses buzzer beside Brandon's door. Brandon opens it,  Killaine nods to him, passes him on the way in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Killaine enters, stops, looking around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to have kept you waiting,  Mrs. West, Mr.  Clarendon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to Betty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Mayfield. There's not much I  can do tonight. But there is one  thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves across to Clarendon, takes gun and handkerchief  out of his pocket and holds it so only Clarendon can see  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Clarendon, have you ever seen  this before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking down) I'm sorry, Inspector, I don't know  much about..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply) Recently, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly) No, Not recently. I'm sure of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves to Margo, holds gun in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. West?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margo's eyes go down very slowly. She stares at the gun  for a long moment before speaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a choked voice) I never saw it before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Positive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margo lifts her face to him and nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I've seen it before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine reacts sharply. Killaine catches the reaction  with the corner of his eye, but appears not to pay any  attention. Brandon obviously does see the reaction.   Killaine turns back to Brandon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Miss Mayfield's balcony.. beside  the chaise, I picked it up. Don't  ask me why. I ought to know better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite sure you had no motive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine glances sidewise at Betty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I rather thought so. And before  that, had you ever seen the gun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margo is seen to react with great relief which she tries  to conceal. Killaine gives another quick sidelong look.   Brandon has continued to watch her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Brandon) It was lying where on the balcony?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Near his right hand. About a foot  away. Perhaps more. Good heavens,  one doesn't use a tape measure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We do, when we get the chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine turns so that he faces Margo and Clarendon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I needn't keep you any longer, Mr.  Clarendon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing up) Thank you. It is rather late...  and I'm not young anymore. Good  night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not quiet yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crosses and opens door. Clarendon goes out. Killaine  shuts door, goes to Margo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You knew Mitchell pretty well,  didn't you, Mrs. West?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was in love with him... which  shows you the quality of my brains. (bursting out-- looking at Betty) Why don't you ask her about the  gun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shall. From your knowledge of  Mitchell, would you say he would  be likely to commit suicide?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anybody could commit suicide, if  he felt low enough. I've felt it  myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why not give Miss Mayfield  the benefit of the doubt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd be delighted to... anytime you  can show me the doubt. I'll wrap  it up in tissue paper and put a  Christmas seals on it for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you very much, Mrs. West.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margo flounces to door, jerks it open before anybody can  get there to hold it for her, and goes out, banging the  door after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about a cup of coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks. I had some. How would  you like to take a walk for, say,  half and hour?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon glances at Betty, then back at Killaine, Shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crosses, gets hat and coat, goes to door and out.   Killaine turns to Betty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. West is a very emotional woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know her.. or particularly  want to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You probably know the type. You  find them in hotels and resorts  all over the world. They always  have clothes, and money, and usually  have had three or four husbands.  They dress and enamel themselves  with great care. They worry a great  deal about those little lines at  the corner of the eyes.. And they  demonstrate their incompetence at  the art of living bet getting mixed  up with people like Larry Mitchell. (a beat) Tell me about yourself, Miss  Mayfield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was born in New York City. I  grew up. And here I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have to know a little more  than that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, that's all there is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Mayfield, the humor of the  situation escapes me. Within 24  hours I shall know officially  whether Mitchell was murdered.   Privately, I'm quite sure of it  now. It happened in your room, and  you came to Vancouver with him..  At any rate, he made your hotel  reservation.. And you arrived  together. Here in this room he  behaved nastily to you, and you  said something to him which might  be taken as a threat.  A few hours  later he was found dead on your  balcony. Would it be too much too  suggest that all these circumstances  taken together are a little  suspicious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please answer my question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't ask a question. You  made a speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's an evasion and you know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their eyes meet in a long stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is some moonlight. In the foreground, the back of a man seated in a chair. Door opens, Margo is silhouetted  against corridor light. She switches light on, shuts door turns, and reacts violently. Clarendon is sitting in chai with his cane between his knees. CAMERA PANS her over to  Clarendon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tensely) What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think you locked your door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See how easy it is? Perhaps Miss  Mayfield left her door unlocked.   Or if she didn't, there's a passkey  on every floor in the linen room.  The head porter has a passkey. The  bell captain has a passkey. The  hotel's full of passkeys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passkey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or--since one is a well-known and  respected guest--one could go to  the desk in the lobby and say "Miss  Mayfield seems to have lost her  room key--have you another"?  They  always have another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be a fool. I loved him. He  wasn't worth it, but I loved him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now that he's safe from all  other women, you can go on loving  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You nasty, sardonic--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sardonic, if you will my dear.   Bust nasty. You lied about the  gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margo reacts, shocked. Clarendon gets slowly to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a very observant man. You had  something in your bag this  afternoon, Something that causes  you to hold it in a particular  way. Something that made a  particular sound when you put it  down on the bar. You went out with  Mitchell. None of us ever saw him  again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (desperately) That's not enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw your face this evening when  the detective showed you the gun.   You lied. It was obvious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He saw my face too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So he did--but he hasn't told you  what he saw. I have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll arrest that girl.   Everything points to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Convenient, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of these days, you're going to  wake up in the middle of the night  and find that you've cut your  throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How clumsy. I'd never forgive  myself. Good night my dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could have got in that room,  just as you got in here. How do I  know you didn't kill Larry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With what motive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nastiness. You're nasty with words.  Why wouldn't you be nasty with  deeds once in a while? You hated  him--and I know why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was very easy to hate. If you'll  look in your mirror, when you are  in a better temper- you'll know  why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margo just stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very silly of me, isn't it? I'm  not as well-off as I was once- and  I'm used to my little comforts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He exits. Margo looks after him, thunderstruck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine is standing at wall, looking out over view. He i smoking. He points up with cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That star up there is Alphard.  "The lonely", they call him. I  wonder why he's lonely? Perhaps  he's a policeman--a celestial  policeman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS BACK to include Betty, who is staring at him He turns slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's not getting us  anywhere. You won't tell me who  you are, or give any account of  yourself. You won't even give me  your address in the United States.  Why? Unhappy marriage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who told you I was married?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's the clear mark of a wedding  ring on your finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns, walks abruptly away, then back into the living room. Killaine follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Killaine enters. Betty is already inside. She sits dow

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room's full of cigarettes.   But of course one would have to be  handed to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes to her, takes out sliver case, and opens it. She  takes one, is about to return the case to his pocket when

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me see that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds case out to her. There is an inlaid design on it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your family coat of arms, Mr.   Killaine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crossly) Regimental! Seaforth Highlanders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop saying you're sorry. I want  information, not regrets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you be satisfied if I said I  shot him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine jerks the wrapped gun out of his pocket and thru it in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's you get it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A graduation present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine puts the gun back in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a rather inferior grade  humor. But since you're being so  frank, would you mind telling me  why all the labels have been removed  from your clothes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty is jarred. She doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An unhappy marriage hardly seems a  sufficient reason for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you arrest me and be  done with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I probably shall--after I've  tortured you a little more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOUND OF ROOM DOOR OPENING OFF: Killaine looks towards it Brandon comes in and shuts door, throws hat and coat to  one side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you two getting along?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delightfully. Every time Miss  Mayfield says something, I know  less than I did before. (a beat) Well, I may as well knock off for  tonight. (turns to Betty) Good night, Miss Mayfield. Do let  me thank you for your cooperation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's one thing I may as well  tell you. You'll find it out anyhow.  I tried to run away--when I found  him out there on the balcony. There  wasn't any plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't have to tell him that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dryly) Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up his trench coat and starts to put it on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Especially as I already knew it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes out. They watch him leave. As the door closes,  Brandon turns to Betty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He could hardly help suspecting  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's putting it mildly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks across to French doors and stands looking out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over shoulder) What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at watch) Quarter after one. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a lot of night left to  live through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So there is. You don't want to go  to bed. I don't want to go to bed.  Let's go somewhere and hear some  music--have something to drink-- something to eat--even dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dance? Tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's not pretend Mitchell meant  anything to either of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly not to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just who are you, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You, too? (a beat) My name is Betty Mayfield. I was  born, and I am here. Message ends.  That's what I told him. He didn't  like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm different. I like it fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine is standing at the desk, holding a registration  card in his hand. A clerk is across the desk from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice writing--but no information (he hands the card  back to clerk) I didn't expect any.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elevator comes down, doors open. Betty and Brandon come  out. Killaine turns, sees them. Brandon crosses to Killai

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Mayfield would like a little  fresh air. Any objections?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In case you want to have us  followed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well--good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine looks past him at Betty. Their eyes meet. Killai turns away quickly. Brandon rejoins Betty and they start  out of scene.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT
dialogues.text: Lobby is very empty. A short, thick-set MAN is trimming a cigar in a chain. They pass in front of him. He looks up, stares hard at Betty. Betty meets his glance, looks away  quickly. CAMERA STOPS AND HOLDS ON SEATED MAN. He looks  after them, puts away his pocket knife, lights cigar  leisurely, stands up, goes after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mooring slips on one side, below a sea wall. On the other side, a row of nondescript buildings, a few which have  electric signs, one of them an old-fashioned winking  electric sign. It is a run-down neighborhood and tough.   Brandon's convertible enters shot, pulls over to curb in  front of blinking sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sign is now seen to be "CHARLIE'S" but the "R" is half  out, dead bulbs. Car stops, Brandon and Betty get out.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDON AND BETTY ON SIDEWALK IN FRONT OF CHARLIE'S.
dialogues.text: Betty is shivering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cold?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this the best you can do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this time of night. It's not as  bad as it looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little reluctantly, she crosses sidewalk with him, they go into swinging double doors. As the doors open, sounds  of very bad dance music is heard. Doors swing shut again. CAMERA PULLS BACK AND PANS SLOWLY ACROSS THE STREET, as  the nondescript little car with dim lights comes up to  curb and stops some way behind Brandon's convertible. Lig go out, and the short, tick-set man from the lobby of the hotel gets out of car, walks along to Brandon's car, lean in, pokes a small pencil flash at the registration on the steering post, takes out a notebook, makes a note in it,  puts notebook and flash away, crosses to swinging doors,  starts in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The decor is strictly Gas-house Gothic. There are booths  like horse stalls, also round scarred tables and hard  chairs. The dance band on plain wooden platform, composed of five old young men, plays moodily and contemptuously. There isn't a thing in the joint that could be damaged by being dropped out of a third-story window. At one table  sits a NAVY SAILOR across from a BLOUSY GIRL. There is an empty glass in front of him. He sits very straight, vacan eyed, stupid drunk. A chunky grim-looking character in a  dinner jacket comes by table, pauses to glance at sailor, makes a signal to girl, who nods. CAMERA PANS him across  to booth in which Brandon and Betty have just sat down.  The MAN in dinner jacket is MAGRUDER. He owns the joint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to see you, Mr. Brandon--and  the lady. What'll you take?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glancing at Betty) Scotch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty nods lifelessly; to Magruder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scotch. The kind you buy, Magruder,  not the kind you make.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only the best for you, Mr.  Brandon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He signals a waiter, goes out of shot. Band starts to pla Betty looks out of booth.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDON'S POV
dialogues.text: Three couples start to lumber around the small dance floo The air is heavy with smoke. The soused sailor and blousy girl come dancing into foreground. Sailor is dancing with all the grace of a rhinoceros.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you need is a drink, big boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly pushing  her away) Aw, go blow your nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts back to table. Girl shrugs resignedly, goes aft him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is staring horrified at this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you bring me to such a  place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (casually) There isn't anywhere else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waiter comes up and serves drinks. Brandon tastes it to  make sure he gets what he orders, nods his head. Betty  seizes glass almost convulsively and takes a long swallow

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want to dance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dance? Here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staring at him) They know you here--know your name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know everybody. I don't look at  half of life, just the nice half,  I look at all of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty finishes off her drink, then in a reckless, half- wild voice,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, then, let's dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They get up out of booth and about to start dancing when  Betty's gaze becomes fixed on something across the room.

dialogues.speaker: WHAT HE SEES
dialogues.text: Thick-set MAN from the lobby sitting alone at a table wit a bottle of beer in front of him. He is staring over at  Betty and Brandon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That man over there. He was in the  hotel lobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he looks across) I didn't notice him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We walked right passed him. He's  following us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine's not that sort of guy.   He said no--he meant no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then he's got to be a detective.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couldn't be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then he's-- (she breaks off,  stares rigidly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon looks at her curiously, not getting it. Betty  swallows and then gets her voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take me out of here, please.  Right  away. (Brandon just keeps  looking at her.) If you don't I'll go alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon reaches for her coat, puts it around her, throws  some money on the table. They start across room. Brandon  deliberately steers past the thick-set man, who is pourin himself a glass of beer. He doesn't even look up. Brandon and Betty reach the top of the stairs. Brandon looks back

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite sure you saw him in the hotel  lobby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his eyes narrow a  little) We'll find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns, takes Betty's arm, they start down the stairs,  CAMERA PANS OVER TO MAN. He now looking after them with  half smile on his face. He lifts his glass of beer in  salute, drinks it down, stands up.

dialogues.speaker: FOOT OF STAIRS JUST INSIDE SWINGING DOORS
dialogues.text: It is pretty dark. It is not a solid stairway, there is a space behind it. Brandon notes this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go out and get in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty hesitates, then starts out. Brandon looks back  upstairs. SOUND OF DESCENDING STEPS OVER SHOT. Brandon  goes quickly around stairway almost out of sight. Thick- set man comes down the stairs. He is now trimming another cigar. As he reaches the bottom of stairs, he stops, take out a match, and is about to strike it then Brandon steps out.  The man looks at him unemotionally, cigar and match in midair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The light's bad in here, but I  seem to remember the face. What  was the name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man smiles, doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, let's see the buzzer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's a buzzer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're not a cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me a cop? What made you think that,  Mr. Brandon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who told you my name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got good ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon steps up close to him, grabs the lapels of his  coat, and twists a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tightly) How are your teeth getting along?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) The new ones are fine. The last  set I had gave me all kinds of  trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks down at Brandon's hand, holding the lapels of hi coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this in favor of?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like to be tailed. The  lady I'm with doesn't like to be  stared at. To put the matter in a  couple of nutshells, I don't like  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still smiling, the man brings his knee up hard. Brandon  reels away from him, groaning, doubles up against the wal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna get tough, Mr. Brandon,  you gotta know the technique.   Next time, turn a little sideways,  get your hip in the way. See what  I mean? Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes through the double doors. CAMERA STAYS ON BRANDON He straightens up slowly, gets out handkerchief, mops his forehead. He has been hurt pretty badly. After a while, h stiffens himself by main force, walks to door, pushes it  open, starts out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands, breathing hard, looking off.

dialogues.speaker: WHAT HE SEES
dialogues.text: Thick-set man is getting into his car. He starts it up,  turns the light on, turns and goes out of shot.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO BRANDON
dialogues.text: He crosses sidewalk slowly to his convertible. Betty is  waiting in it. Without a word, Brandon goes around, gets  in behind the wheel. He sits there with his hands on the  wheel, taking deep breaths.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (urgently) Who is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon turns his head slowly to look at her. He speaks a little quickly, still in pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a fellow with a very hard  knee, and he knows how to use it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know who he is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not a cop. A cop wouldn't  have kneed me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly) He was following us--but he's not  a policeman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right--following me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No matter. There's nothing I can  do about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything I can do about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take me home--and forget you ever  saw me. That's a silly remark isn't  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try not talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts an arm around her and pulls her close to him as i to kiss her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It still doesn't matter if I kiss  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing matters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No use waiting, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kisses her on the mouth, hard. She doesn't resist and  she doesn't respond. He pulls his head away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the second round I've lost  tonight. (he moves and winces) That fellow hurt me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So have I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From you, I like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts the car. It goes off down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Showing desk, elevator bank, guests reading morning paper in chairs. In background the dining room entrance through which can be seen part of the dining room, with waiters  moving back and forth etc. It is breakfast time. Betty  appears in dining room entrance, coming out.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS with her as she moves across lobby to desk.   Room clerk is checking in several new arrivals. Luggage,  bellboys, etc. Betty moves along the desk to far end, sta waiting. Hotel manager comes up to her. He pretends not t know her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning. Can I do something  for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Miss Mayfield. Is Mr.  Campbell  here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Mr. Campbell, Miss Mayfield. (slight pause) Purely as a matter of routine, I  want to ask the name of your bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bank?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very smoothly) Merely for our records, Miss  Mayfield. It's usual for the guests  who come here for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (opening her bag) I'm carrying quite a large sum in  Travelers checks. How much of a  deposit would you like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't dream if questioning  your credit. Purely a matter of  routine, for the hotel records.   Just the name of your bank--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He breaks off, glances over to one side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She notices the glance and turns her head, looks off in  the same direction, reacts, looks back at Campbell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply) The Hotel records, Mr. Campbell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brightly) I'm afraid I've been clumsy.  Please  overlook it, Miss Mayfield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a quick nod Betty turns away. CAMERA PANS her over t extreme end of desk. Killaine stands there idly, with an  elbow on the desk. Betty comes up to him. She is angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. Killaine. I'm  sorry I can't give you the name of  my bank--because I have no bank at  the moment. (pause) That was a crude trick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're all crude, when they don't  work. Had breakfast?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Care for a stroll outside?   Beautiful morning. The air is like  wine, the sky is a deep blue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (contemptuously) Deep blue? I'd call it grey-blue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must come from pretty far South.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She bites her lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLorida?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never been to Florida.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine smiles and moves away from desk, and she falls i beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Metal lettering on it reads CLARK BRANDON ENTERPRISES.   Below that to one side ENTER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A middle-aged SECRETARY is at a desk. a MAN sitting over  to one side, reading a newspaper. He is short, thick-set, wears heavy glasses. These are phony glasses--they just  look heavy--there is a clear spot in the middle. DOOR OPE OFF. Brandon enters shot, goes across to desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. Brandon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning. Any calls?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Reed would like you to call  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Get him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking off) And there's a Mr. Goble to see  you. Says his business is personal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's Goble?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS OVER TO MAN with glasses. He puts his newspap away, stands up, crosses to Brandon, CAMERA PANNING HIM  BACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Goble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon looks at him. Nothing in his face shows recogniti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like a few words with you, in  private.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not interested in blind dates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goble takes his glasses off, puts then away, and stares a Brandon, who reacts just enough to show he has recognized Goble. During this, secretary has dialed

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Mr. Reed, please, for Mr.  Brandon. (pause) Very well. Have him call. Mr.   Brandon is in his office now. (she hangs up) Mr. Reed stepped out, Mr.  Brandon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Goble) This way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crosses to door, opens it, goes in, leaving Goble to  follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon round desk, takes off hat, stands looking down at some letters on his desk. DOOR CLOSES BEHIND Goble, who  has entered. Goble crosses calmly to chair, sits down.  Brandon gets cigarette out and lights it with desk lighte without offering Goble one, and blows a little smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Talk it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goble gets a card out of his wallet, hands it across.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) "Martin Goble. Insurance Adjuster."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drops card on desk, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice friendly approach you've got.  Goble. I could hardly walk when I  got out of bed this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You asked for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm still asking. What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure I want anything from  you. You might want something from  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Name it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Information--protection--you might  even want to hire me to go home  and listen to the radio.  That's  the funny part of my business-- once in a while, I get hired not  to work. (pause) Nice girl you were with last night.  Known her long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon picks the card off the desk, tosses it into waste paper basket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Private eye?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guessed it. The card's phony.   I got plenty of 'em. Different  names, different jobs. I work out  of San Francisco. Go anywhere, do  anything. All it takes is the  folding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are your rates?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: $40 a day and expenses. Expenses  run pretty high on a case like  this. I'm a long way from home. I  don't have a B.C. Licence. I'd  need about $500 for a retainer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you got on Miss Mayfield?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mayfield? Oh, that girl you were  with last night. You haven't hired  me yet. Mr. Brandon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon moves quickly around the desk, grabs Goble, and  jerks him to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with cold savagery) That's a nice hard knee you've  got, Goble. How'd you like to trade  it for a broken neck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly) Quit trying to scare me, Mr.   Brandon, I'm neurotic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know whether to knock your  teeth down your throat--or call  the police--or just give you twenty  bucks to go out and buy yourself a  clean nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon hurls him away. Goble staggers back, without losi his balance. He smiles. Brandon stares back at him savage for a moment, then goes back around his desk and sits dow

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hurt my feelings. I ought to  raise the price to be a thousand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I call the police, your price  will go down to a minus sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bluff. You've waited too long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For five hundred, what do I get?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I go home and paint the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For two hundred?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I stick around and wait for the  five hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mentioned information.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. Another client paid for  that. You can hire me not to use  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thousand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitates--then) Got it on you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got the information on you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get it in half an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon takes out his wallet, takes some bills out of it, throws then across the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's two hundred. I'll meet you  in an hour--where we met last night

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like your perfume in my  office. Make it somewhere else if  you don't like Charlie's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie's suits me fine. I don't  scare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches for the money, stands up and puts it in his  pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You pay the check, you pick the  joint. See you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He exits scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty and Killaine are learning on a wall, looking out  over Puget Sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down below's Stanley Park. On the  other side of the trees, there's a  beach. You can see it. (points over to  left) Steveston's over there. Coast Guard  station. (points to right) There's the Yacht Club, and beyond  it, the docks. The over on the  other side of the inlet, there's  Grouse Mountain. It's about 4000  feet high. There's a restaurant on  top of it. Very nice restaurant. (he turns to Betty) I'm sorry we couldn't have met in  pleasanter circumstances, Miss  Mayfield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We wouldn't have met at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: True. I was a bit irritable last  night. I apologize.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were a galahad, compared to  some cops I've known.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pouncing--but very  quietly) You've had dealings with the police  before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who hasn't--one way or another?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But not in the investigation of a  major crime, I hope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it a crime?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're 98 per cent certain Mitchell  was murdered. There are a lot of  reasons. (pause) Was he very drunk when you last  saw him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were there when I last saw  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to believe that. It's not  too easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty says nothing. Killaine looks away again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been talking to the Immigration  Inspector who passed you across  the border. He was a little  suspicious of you.  Mayfield isn't  really your name, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty looks straight ahead, doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll find out, you know. Perhaps  not today--perhaps not tomorrow.   But in the end, I'll find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police always do, don't they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've has an experience that you  don't want to talk about. An unhappy  marriage, for example.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty turns away quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't make you talk about it.  My job is the death of Marry  Mitchell.  Why can't you give me  your confidence?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You--or the Vancouver Police  Department?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We try to be decent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a police officer. A very  nice one--but you have a job to  do. I'm a girl who's in a jam, and  it's your job to keep me there.  Don't go considerate on me. I might  start to bawl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their eyes meet in a long look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't tell me who you are?   You won't even give me a chance to  help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody can help me. You, least of  all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly) If I understand what you meant by  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You understand perfectly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then there isn't much I can do, is  there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There isn't anything you can do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves towards her, then turns abruptly and goes.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CHARLIE'S PLACE
dialogues.text: Chairs are piled up on the tables. A MAN with a mop is  going over the floor. STEPS ARE HEARD. Goble, the private eye comes into the SHOT slowly. His eyes are very wary. H has a hand in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came here to see Mr. Brandon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon. I was to meet him here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Ask the boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He jerks his thumb backwards, and Goble moves off in that direction.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA FOLLOWS GOBLE
dialogues.text: Though open door. He stands a moment, looking along the  hallway, listening. There is no sound at all. He reaches door CAMERA PANS AROUND to show small plate on the door  with the word MANAGER. Goble listens again, takes the gun out of his pocket, looks at it, puts it back, keeping his hand on it, opens the door, and stars in.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CHARLIE'S PLACE
dialogues.text: It is what you would expect. Magruder is at a desk, doing some bookkeeping work. He looks up indifferently as Goble ENTERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm looking for Mr. Brandon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The joint's not open, Mac.  Who's  Brandon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goble comes up to the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have an appointment with him,  right here, right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go live in a tent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be a tough dollar when guys  like you learn the alphabet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning) Talk English.  How do I know you're  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goble reaches a hand into his pocket, throws a card on th desk.  Magruder picks it up, reads it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Brandon couldn't be here.  He  might have left something for you.   What would it look like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of those nice long manila  envelopes--sealed.  Not too fat- not too thin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I get for it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get it's brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like a fair swap.  Let's  take a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He jerks open the drawer of his desk.  Gobble stiffens,  his hand on the gun.  Magruder takes out a long sealed  envelope, throws it on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need a receipt.  Sign your name  across the flap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open it and count it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you sign for it, you count  it.  It's your dough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up a desk pen, holds it out.  Goble hesitates,  then takes his right hand holding the gun out of his pock lays the gun down on the desk beside the envelope.  He  takes the pen, leans down to write.  At that instant,  Magruder lunges up swiftly, grabs Goble's right wrist wit his left hand and jerks him forward hard.  Goble tries to reach the gun with his left hand.  Magruder grabs an old- fashioned round ebony ruler up off the desk and smacks  Goble's hard on the head with it twice.  Goble sprawls  across the desk, limp.  Magruder takes the gun, puts it i his pocket, picks up the envelope, tears it open, and sha out the money, counts it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight hundred bucks.  Ice cream  for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Magruder picks the gun up, balances it on his hand.

dialogues.speaker: MOVE IN ON THE GUN
dialogues.text: It is a .32 caliber revolver, with part of the barrel saw off to make it a belly gun.  It has no front sight. Magruder stares down at it.  PULL AWAY as he turns, pulls open desk drawer, puts gun in it, shuts drawer.  He round the desk, reaches inside Goble's pocket, pulls out a thic manila envelope, stands looking down at it, speculating,  tries the flap to see if it will come loose.

dialogues.speaker: MOVE IN TO SHOW THERE IS NO WRITING ON THE ENVELOPE
dialogues.text: He picks up the envelope which contained money.  It is  also manila and about the same size.  With a quick decisi Magruder tears open GOBLE'S ENVELOPE, draws out a sheaf o blank paper.  Magruder whistles lightly between his teeth turns his head to state at Goble who is still limp, spraw across the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) You had it coming, didn't you,  baby? (reaches across,  shakes Goble's  shoulders) Come on.  You're not that sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goble does not respond.  Magruder pulls his head and  shoulder up on the desk.  The head sags to one side.   Magruder presses a thumb against one of Goble's eyeballs. No reaction.  Magruder bends close, stares, and is sudden stiff with fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hoarsely) Don't tell me you had a glass head,  baby.  Oh no--not in your business.   How could you live so long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lets go of Goble who sways sideways in the chair, his  head hanging like that of a broken doll.  As Magruder sta down at him, with very much the sort of frozen horror as  we saw on Betty's face when she found Mitchell's body on  the balcony.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Small bare room, empty.  Door opens.  Sergeant Gore users Margo in through a side door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down, Mrs. West.  Inspector  Killaine will be along in a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gore sits down in a hard wooden chair by Killaine's desk. She is nervous, lights a cigarette, looks at her watch,  gets up suddenly as if to leave before Killaine gets back then shrugs and sits down again, Door opens and Killaine  enters, glances at Margo, goes behind his desk, sits down with his hat on, presses dictagraph key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into dictagraph) Killaine here.  I want a radio  contact to work with Handley.  A  motorcycle officer will do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right away, Inspector.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine disconnects, turns to face Margo, removing his  hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember that time, didn't I?   Good morning Mrs. West.  Does your  visit here mean you've changed  your mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (startled) How did you know? (Killaine smiles  slightly, doesn't  answer) Clarendon. (Killaine still  doesn't answer) You cops never tell anybody  anything, do you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Other people always know so much  more than we know--so much more  than they're willing to tell us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was Clarendon.  He knew I had  the gun in my bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine just stares

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You couldn't possible have traced  it this soon--not possibly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dryly) Of course not.  Thanks for telling  me.  I haven't seen Mr. Clarendon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am a fool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That depends upon your motive.   You were in love with Mitchell,  weren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes--and he's already becoming  vague to me.  Funny!  Last night I  was furiously jealous.  Jealous of  what?  I out that gun in my bag  deliberately.  Who was I going to  kill with it?  A girl I didn't  even know?  A man I knew to be a  thief and a forger?  A half-man?   A gigolo?  It's already ludicrous.   Love!  What a comedy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't play it for laughs last  night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you ever have a serious  operation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mortar shells are not funny, either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At first, it doesn't hurt at all.   That's shock.  Then it hurts  terribly--you wouldn't believe  such pain could exist--and six  months later you can't remember  what pain felt like. (pause) It hasn't taken six months this  time.  It hasn't even taken twenty- four hours.  Is that a beastly  thing to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not if it clears the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It does.  May I go now? (she stands up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll investigate Mr. Clarendon's  financial position--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps a rich widow would have  solved all his problems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, you're being beastly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.  You didn't come here in  person just to tell me about the  gun.  You wanted me to be looking  across the desk at you while you  talked about Mitchell. (he pauses; Margo  nods--admiration  in her eyes) If I believe you, it would be  psychologically impossible for you  to have killed him last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if you didn't believe me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You would still have planted  information that Clarendon knew  about the gun--and not as an  accusation, but in the process of  defending yourself by making a  confession.  Very neat.  Good  morning, Mrs. West.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her expression changes.  She gives him an icy stare, and  goes out quickly.  Dictagraph BUZZES.  He depressed key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into speaker) Killaine here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come into my office, please,  Killaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into speaker) Right away, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He releases the key, starts out

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Killaine comes out of his office, walks along briskly, comes to a door, stops.

dialogues.speaker: DOOR
dialogues.text: It is lettered SUPERINTENDENT J. McKECHNIE. Killaine KNOCKS, then starts in without waiting for an  answer.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: McKechnie is at his desk.  He is a military-looking Scotc Canadian, with a white mustache.  Beside the desk sits an elderly, prim-looking man in a dark suit with a black tie Killaine comes up to desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine, this is Mr. Mitchell,  Senior.  Young Mitchell's father.   He just flew in from Toronto.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mitchell) How do you do, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitchell nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've explained the situation to  Mr. Mitchell up to a point.  Now  about this Mayfield girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a suspect, naturally.  But  not the only one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (harshly) She's the only one who had a dead  man in her room.  The only one who  won't give an account of herself.   The only one who tried to run away.   And the only one, so far, I've  been told, who went to such lengths  to disguise her identity that she  even removed the labels from her  clothes.  What more do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She should have been arrested last  night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's as may be. (to Killaine) We've ample grounds to detain her  for questioning.  You can't deny  that, surely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear she's a very pretty girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which forces me to arrest her  against my better judgment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye.  You have a point there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If so, I must say that it escapes  my attention.  It is my son who  has been murdered.  He was not  always a good son--but he was my  son.  I want his murderer punished.   The girl's obviously a criminal of  some sort.  Otherwise, she'd give  an account of herself.  Arrest  her, and you'll find out soon  enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyeing Killaine) I think he's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing up) Am I to interpret that as an order  to arrest Miss Mayfield?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I give an order, you'll not  need it interpreted. (glances up at clock  on wall) You have an hour to make your mind  up. (he turns to  Mitchell, Sr.) Well, are ye satisfied, Mr.  Mitchell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be satisfied when my son's  murderer is convicted and hanged. (pause--his  expression softens  a little) You've given this young man a very  difficult choice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye.  That was the point you said  you didn't get. (he turns back to  Killaine) That's all. (makes a gesture of  dismissal)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns.  We PAN HIM TO THE DOOR, he starts out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine comes from Mckechnie's office.  Starts back to  towards his own office. Another plain clothes cop, DRISCOLL, is walking towards  Killaine.  They meet just outside Killaine's office.   Driscoll is a tall, solemn-looking Irishman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I have a moment, Inspector?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Harbor police have just picked  up a dead man out of the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Floater?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a floater.  Only just dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting to turn  away) You're the waterfront specialist.   Find out about it.  I've got a  murder to investigate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have two murders to investigate.   This man's head was beaten in.   And there's nothing in his pockets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drunk-rolling job.  They hit him  too hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (annoyed with his  manner) I've been on the waterfront detail  for twelve years.  This man hadn't  been dead an hour.  He wasn't killed  last night.  He was killed today.   In broad daylight.  That's no drunk- rolling job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting to turn  away again) Let me know when you've identified  him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Driscoll gives him a somber look and starts to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling after him) And don't get too logical, Driscoll.   In police business it doesn't work.   I wish it did.  But it doesn't

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking back) I'm an Irishman, sir.  An Irishman  is always logical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine frowns, then starts into his own little office.

dialogues.speaker: ALONG THE SIDEWALK
dialogues.text: A MAN in a business suit is leaning against it, He is a  plain-clothes dick by the name of HANDLEY.  Other PEOPLE  are standing near him, looking through the railing, as if waiting for something to happen.  Handley is looking in  the other direction, along the sidewalk.  In the backgrou SOME TRAFFIC NOISE, and far off, BLAST OF A TUG WHISTLE. Handley gets a cigarette out and lights it, with his eyes still looking off to the side. CAMERA PANS SLOWLY ALONG THE RAILING, showing people  standing in groups looking through.  CAMERA PICKS UP BETT AMONG THEM.  Near at hand there is a SHARP WHISTLE BLAST, and immediately snare drums are HEARD, first in spaced  tap, then going into a tattoo.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICIAL-LOOKING BUILDING
dialogues.text: Built of stone, with broad steps.  The Union Jack flies  from a flagpole.  On the space in front of the building,  two small groups of soldiers is in battle-dress, and the  band, which marches it, is a bugle and drum band, also in battle-dress.  The other group is in the dress uniform of the Seaforth Highlanders, with kilts, Glengarry's, etc.,  and their band is a piper's band, in kilts.  What is taki place is a guard mount.  The old guard is stood at attent and inspected by the outgoing officer of the day; and dur this inspection the drums and bugle band march up and dow in front of them, playing.  The inspection over, the old  guard will be formed into a marching column, the drum and bugle band will take position ahead of them, and the whol outfit will march across the parade ground and back again while the new guard stands at attention, its band silent. The old guard will then be halted, and faced towards the  new guard, and will present arms.  Then it will march off behind its band, while the kiltie guard is called to  attention and presents arms.  The outgoing and incoming  officers of the day will salute each other.  As the old  guard marches off, their band will stop playing, and the  pipers will march and start playing the bagpipes.  This  will continue while the new guard is inspected.  The new  guard will be marched will be marched off behind the pipe and the ceremony is over.  This is the background of the  following scenes, and is going on all the time.  Whatever portion of it is to be shown in immaterial, but the sound of it will be heard always, louder, not so loud, not loud at all, according to what is going on and how far off the bands are. Betty is staring through the railing as the drum and bugl band goes into its tattoo and starts marching.  A moment  later, the bugles join in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is looking off in the other direction, makes a signal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A motorcycle officer standing beside the curb, bears his  motorcycle which has a side-car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into mike) Go ahead, three-eight-six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Party I am detailed to observe is  watching guard mount in front of  Parliament Buildings.  Sergeant  Handley is standing by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (NOTE: There is no Parliament Buildings in Vancouver.   They are in Victoria, so some substitute must be found.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into mike) Message received.  Stand by.  One- two-five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He scribbles something on a pad, tears off and holds out  behind him without looking.  A uniformed POLICE OFFICER  takes it.

dialogues.speaker: HANDLEY
dialogues.text: Standing by railing, watching Betty.  DRUM AND BUGLE MUSI OVER SCENE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crowd against railing, Motorcycle Officer in foreground A CAR ENTERS SHOT, stops behind motorcycle.

dialogues.speaker: CAR
dialogues.text: Killaine gets out, crosses to Motorcycle Officer, who  salutes him, then points out a scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take over now.  Wait for  Handley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts walking CAMERA WITH HIM, comes up with Handley, leans against the railing beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm relieving you, Handley.  Carry  on with Gore at the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Handley gives Killaine a curious look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes out of shot.  Killaine watches him, then moves  along the railings (the guard mount ceremony is continuin all this time), comes up beside Betty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't a very good place to  talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've come here to arrest you for  murder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over scene -- very  sharp and military) Guard HALT!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right TURN!

dialogues.speaker: A SOUND OF FEET, A STAMP, A SLAPPING OF HANDS AGAINST RIF
dialogues.text: SLINGS as guard brings its arms to order.  Betty turns he head to look at Killaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I expected nothing else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might be able to save you.  If I  knew enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't even try (Killaine reacts,  hurt) There must be some copper in you,  or you wouldn't be an inspector.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There must be-- but when I'm with  you I can't find it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over scene) Guard, Present ARMS!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning and looking  through railing) Everybody loves a guard mount-- except the guard. (looks back) My boss gave me an hour to make up  my mind.  The time's almost up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the first time in the scene, Betty turns and faces  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm about to be very silly.  A man  passes a girl on the street--a  very lovely girl--his eyes meet  her eyes, and something reaches  out and takes hold of his heart-- and then she goes on and is lost  in the crowd--and he says to  himself, "There goes my lost love"-- and it's true--if he never sees  her again, it's still true.  Of  course, after a while, he forgets-- or almost forgets--because after a  while we forget almost everything. (Betty is silent,  staring at him) But this man is a copper.  He gets  orders--routine orders--to go to a  place and investigate a murder-- and everything points to a certain  girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Points very straight to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at the girl, looks into  her eyes--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does he see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Palm trees against a sunset--waves  breaking on a coral reef--the Taj  Mahal by moonlight--roses in an  English garden, just after a shower-- (he grins wryly) ClichГ©s, one and all--but good  ones, with a lot of mileage left  in them--there's one thing he does  not see--murder--and murder was  what he was sent to find.  Pretty  ridiculous, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my hard luck--I'm man enough  to tell you about it--and not be  sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do your friends call you?-- The ones that know you well?--and  like you very much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They call me Jeff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff.  Shall we go now, Jeff, and  get it over with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not quiet yet. (pause) We know who the gun belonged to.   Margo West.  She told us this  morning. (pause) It doesn't mean much.  Mitchell  took it away from her.  He had a  habit of going through her bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking for peanuts, I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Mitchell had handled it.   Afterwards, Brandon picked it up. (he glances at her) There's no indication you handled  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always wear gloves when I shoot  people.  A bad joke--but better  than tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glancing at his  watch again) Time's up.  I'm off the case. (he takes a deep  breath)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll only find someone else-- who won't be so kind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's something I can't spare  you.  But I won't do it myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you think your in love  with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm enough of a copper to do my  duty.  My boss made it tough for  me.  If I don't arrest you, I've  gone soft.  If I do, it's to save  my face.  I don't play those rules.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He breaks off.  PIPE MUSIC SOUNDS OVER SCENE.  Killaine  raises his voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got a couple of hours, maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To do what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't answer that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What will they do to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's they're business.  Can I  drop you somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're still a police officer,  Jeff. (pause) I saw you send those two men away.   I know they were watching me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine stares at her silently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to do--toss  your job into Puget Sound?  Because  I make you think of magnolias?  I  thought policeman was something  like a soldier.  That his duty  came first.  However much he might  happen hate it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (steadily) I've been a soldier too.  There is  a difference.  A policeman, like a  judge, has a right to disqualify  himself on proper grounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What proper grounds? (pause, Killaine  doesn't answer) You can't be in love with me.  You  hardly know me.  I'm not in love  with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But even if you were in love with  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost rudely) There's an empty taxi across the  street.  If you're so anxious,  take it.  He'll know the way to  the police headquarters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do things the hard way, don't  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not sometimes.  Always.  Just  because it is the hard way.  You're  that kind of man, Jeff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Betty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty doesn't answer.  She shakes her head slightly, stan with a little smile on her face.  He turns, goes quickly  out of scene.  The guard mount ceremony ends.  The crowd  begins to break up.  Betty glances across the street, the starts out.

dialogues.speaker: AN EMPTY TAXICAB, THE FLAG UP
dialogues.text: The driver is parked by the curb.  He has been watching  the guard mount and is ow waiting for a fare.  He sees  one, gets quickly out of the cab, opens the door as Betty COMES INTO SHOT.  She gets into the cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where to, Miss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Downtown somewhere--anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right you are, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shuts a door, starts around his car, as we

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: McKechnie behind his desk.  Killaine standing across from him.  (We enter the middle of scene)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you a policeman or a soft-headed  nincompoop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little of both, sir, and perhaps  not quiet enough of either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It won't look pretty good on your  record, Killaine.  Where's the  girl now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, find out.  Who's covering  her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody's covering her, I detached  the officer assigned to that duty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McKechnie comes slowly to his feet.  His voice is very  quiet, and very dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This girl is a murderess, Killaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I disagree, sir.  As Inspector in  charge of the case I have the right  to form that opinion, the right to  act on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ye have, have ye?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We lifted seven fairly good prints  from Miss Mayfield's toilet  articles.  Washington ought to  teletype us within a few hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in the same deadly  quiet voice) And in the meantime this girl goes  where she pleases, does what she  pleases?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McKechnie's eyes go down to his desk.  His hand goes over slowly to a yellow telegraph form, face down.  He turns i over, then lifts it and reads in a quiet, measured voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading our loud) "Superintendent J. Mckechnie,  Vancouver Police Department.   Vancouver B.c. Replaying To Your  E.P. teletype classification No.   2684 incomplete.  We advise  identification possible.  Elizabeth  Kinsolving, arrested Greenwater,  North Carolina, January 8, 1948,  on a charge of murder.  Signed,  FBI., Washington, D.C. H. Cleary,  Inspector in charge." (McKechnie looks up  and meets Killaine's  eyes) Have ye any comment, Killaine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Identification on possible, Sir.   Not conclusive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading out loud) "Superintendent J. McKechnie,  Vancouver Police Department.   Replying your inquiry Elizabeth  Kinsolving.  Subject was indicted,  first degree murder her husband,  Lee Kinsolving, January this year.   Guilty verdict set aside by  presiding judge.  Prisoner  discharged, Whereabouts now unknown.   Fingerprint classification"-- (he holds up the  other telegram and  looks at Killaine) And exact correspondence, Killaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine stands white and silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dropping the F.B.I  telegram and  continuing to read  the other) "Physical description: Age 26,  Height 5  1 3/4 inches: Weight,  188 pounds: Light brown hair: Deep  blue eyes: Small, perfectly formed  features: Ears and earlobes small:  Slender build: Wears size 4 AA  shoe: Quiet refined manner: New  York accent: No charges pending.   No prior criminal record.  Mayfield,  Mother's name.  Air-mailing you  photographs today.  Signed Hubert  Tollison, Chief of Police,  Greenwater, North Carolina." (slowly McKechnie  drops this wire on  top of the other --  to Killaine) She bleached her hair, or course. (pause) Would your sensibilities be  offended, if I sent out a general  alarm to pick up this girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you'd be entirely justified,  sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a sudden roar) But you still think she's innocent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: he reaches into his pocket, takes out his badge, places i on the desk, on top of the two telegrams

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you'd like to have this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McKechnie looks down at it without expression, speaks ver slowly,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe you won decorations during  the war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McKechnie picks up the badge and holds it on the flat of  his hand, looking down at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are people in this world who  don't think a police badge is a  badge of honor.  I'm not one of  them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nor I. This is why I gave it to  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (same tone) You're a young man.  You're  romantic.  You think a pretty face  and a clean conscience go together.   You think a soft voice means a  soft heart.  You'll grow out of  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not too far, I hope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
