dialogues.text: (suddenly very  Scotch, the harsh  and eloquent  Covenanter) This badge is not an old newspaper  you can cast down on the desk.  It  is not a thing you can give up as  of no value.  It may be taken from  you--and you may die defending it.   But you'll not use it to make cheap  dramatic gesures with. (pause; Killaine is  rocked back on his  heels) It's a naked steel of the sword of  Justice.  Put it back in your pocket  and hold tight to it--and someday  you might grow into a worthiness  ye lack now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine reaches out and takes the badge.  He looks down  at it, his face bitter and ashamed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are my orders, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I'm wrong about this bit  of a girl.  Go out and prove it  against me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine steps back, salutes, wheels about and exits scen McKechnie looks after him, expressionlessly.  The door  CLOSES off.  He presses a button.  A uniformed OFFICER  enters, McKechnie holds the two telegrams toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Condense these for an immediate  all-stations pick-up order.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: As he enters.  Crosses to his desk, takes a small, steel  mirror out of drawer and examines his chin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves the mirror back until his face is seen in it.   There is a bitter smile on his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kid Galahad.  The Knight of the  White Plume.  Jess Holmes, the  fool killer.  Boy, you look  wonderful in a tank--with the turret  closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During the speech, a door is OPENED off.  Killaine looks  up.  Driscoll is standing inside the room. We are now

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a moment, Inspector?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got a year.  Or a second.   I'm not sure which.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You told me when we'd identified  this fellow--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've done that.  He's a San  Francisco private eye.  Name Martin  J. Goble, G-O-B-L-E.  Had initials  in his hat and for once he lived  where he bought it.  Goble and  Greer is the firm name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still a bit nasty) Swimming with his hat on?  That's  original.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you'd seen the blood on his  head--and some body had to carry  him out to sea--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand.  Pity to mess up a  nice clean boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (registering  controlled anger  at Killaine's manner) I got through to Greer, his partner  in the detective business.  Greer  won't give out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaning back in  his chair, half- closing his eyes) I'd suggest a telegram.  Something  like this: Chief of Police, San  Francisco.  A licensed private  detective named named Martin J.  Goble, address so-and-so, has been  found murdered within our  jurisdiction.  His partner, name  something-something Greer, refuses  to give us any information.   Correction.  Refuses information  necessary to our investigation.   Can you assist?  Signed Detective  Sergeant Driscoll, Vancouver,  British Columbia, Police. (Killaine opens his  eyes, looks at  Driscoll)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Send that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indifferently) Would you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause) If you're asking my opinion, no.   I'd read it to Greer over the phone.   Ask him if he had any objections.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine stands up, glances at his wristwatch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catch me at the Vancouver Royal if  it's important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How important would it have to be?   It's only murder, Inspector.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine goes close to him, suddenly smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Super's just given me the  sweetest dressing down I've ever  had.  I'm still reeling from it.   And believe me, I had it coming.   I apologize.  What you think is  important--I think is important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (answering his smile) Thanks, Inspector.  What are your  orders about this wire to San  Francisco?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men like you don't need orders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns, exits scene.  Driscoll is now smiling broadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens, Brandon comes in, crosses in the directio of the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon comes in from the living room, crosses to wall  safe.  His expression is tight, business-like, his moveme quick, as if he had a lot to do and didn't intend to wast any time.  Opens wall safe, takes a wad of currency from  it, stuffs currency into breast pocket, re-locks safe.  A door buzzer SOUNDS to the door of his apartment.  Brandon reacts, starts to exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon enters from bedroom.  Door buzzer SOUNDS again.   He picks up his hat and coat, goes to door, opens it.   Killaine come past Brandon into room, closing the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time for a little chat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it doesn't take too long.  Drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.  I don't mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon throws hat and coat on couch, crosses to liquor  cabinet, begins to mix a couple of drinks; his back is no turned to Killaine, who saunters across room to French  doors, exits terrace.  Brandon turns with the glasses in  his hands, then starts after Killaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine is standing against the wall corner, looking dow at the point where the terrace overlooks Betty's balcony. Brandon enters from living room carrying glasses, reacts  again, controls himself, crosses to Killaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine turns, takes a glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.  Lovely view you have,  haven't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never notice the view after the  first week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would.  Fancy waking up every  morning with that in your lap. (he gestures towards  the view) Wonderful thing, money is.  Remember  what Somerset Maugham said about  it ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Money is a sort of sixth sense  that gives meaning to all the  others." Very appealing, especially  to a poor man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could we discuss that some other  time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.  Let's discuss Betty Mayfield. (pause) How long since you saw her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple of hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a warrant for her arrest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That must hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've always thought you were a  pretty nice guy, Brandon.  I'd  like to go on thinking so.  If you  tried to help her get away--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would that make me a heel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd be breaking the law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't answer the question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only answer I have for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You passed up a dozen chances to  arrest her.  What toughened you  up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Information.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't kid me.  You don't think she  murdered Mitchell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It could have been an accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That COULD BE TOLD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not if she knew she wouldn't be  believed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your concentrating too hard,  Killaine.  What about Margo West?   She had a motive.  I guess you  know by this time whose gun it  was?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And old man Clarendon?  He had a  motive, too.  Margo and her money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitchell was killed down here. (he points) How could Clarendon get in to do  it? (pause) Or Margo for that matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could Mitchell?  After that  act he put on up here, is it likely  she'd let him in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She didn't have to.  He could have  climbed down from here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon looks down over the wall.  He turns, deadpan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitchell was too drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or just drunk enough.  He was with  her when she registered.  He knew  where her room was.  You were out  most of the evening.  There was a  lot of mess to clean up . Waiters  coming and going, the door standing  open.  Suppose Mitchell came in to  grab a drink for himself, then  wandered out on this balcony, then  realized betty's balcony was just  below yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo in reverse.  Uh-uh.  No sale,  Killaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't buy it.  Okay.  So I  still want Betty Mayfield.  Where  is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phone rings off, in the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me.  My phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns, exits scene.  Killaine stands a moment, looking down from the edge of the terrace, then follows Brandon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon is just lifting the receiver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His expression tightens, he glances quickly towards the  French doors as Killaine appears in them and strolls into the living room.  Brandon turns his back to Killaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Sorry.  It's not very convenient  just now.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: SHOPPERS, MEN, WOMEN and CHILDREN, etc., sitting around. In the background a line of phone booths.  CAMERA PICKS  OUT  a deadpan, nondescript-looking MAN who might be a  dick as he stands up from a chair, crosses towards phone  booths, CAMERA WITH HIM.  Phone booths are all full.  He  stops before a booth, through the glass door of which Bet can be seen on the phone.  She catches his eye, turns awa quickly.  The Man nonchalantly lights a cigarette, leans  against the booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone in booth) I had no right to call you anyway.   I've made you enough trouble.  I-- I think I know what to do--if  they'll let me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her eyes turn to look at the man outside the booth.  He i not looking at her.

dialogues.speaker: BRANDON ON PHONE
dialogues.text: Killaine, behind him in a chair; has picked up a magazine

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (casual voice) It sounds like a fair location.   Could you be a little more exact?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in the Hudson Bay Company's  store.  That man last night--the  one that followed me--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think that's on the market  anymore.  I'd like something much  closer to the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine is listening, but he does not look up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cant be too close for me.  Right  across the street from it suits  me.  Anything else listed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone, low  penetrating voice,  her mouth very  close to the  mouthpiece) There's another man--right outside  the booth here.  I never saw him  Before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're probably mistaken about  that.  Let's get together sand  talk it over.  There's always a  solution to these problems.  But  it must be near the water.  Quite  near-- (pause) Yes, if you don't mind waiting.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY ON PHONE
dialogues.text: Showing the Man is still standing outside the booth.  He  glances in casually.  Betty turns her head into phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close to the water.  Like last  night.  I'll try.  Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up, stands a moment as if mustering her courage then turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Man is standing there, smoking.  Betty opens the door comes out past him, not looking at him, then turns with a quick decision and faces him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to man) I'm sorry I kept you waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has his hand on the knob of the booth door, holding it He smiles quickly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't give it a thought, Miss.   Matter of fact, waiting is my trade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BIG WOMAN pushes past them, starts to leave herself int the booth he is about to enter.  The man reacts smoothly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to big woman) Pardon me, Madam.  Is that your  handkerchief?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points to a spot on the floor behind her.  She steps  back and turns.  He glides into the booth, draws the door shut, winks at Betty through the glass.  Betty hides her  face as she turns away.  The Big Woman is  furious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has just left the phone and crossed to make another  drink, Killaine tosses the magazine aside and stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No more for me, thanks.  Remember  what I said.  I can't interfere  with the law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where would she go, anyway.  Don't  tell me you haven't got her covered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine just looks at him, then nods, turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitchell was a heel.  We both know  that.  Why take it for granted  that somebody in the hotel knocked  him off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You forgetting the gag line,  Killaine.  The police don't take  anything for granted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid they do.  Far too often.   So long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute.  I'll go with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crosses, picks up hat and coat, reaches Killaine at the  door, they start out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (casually) You do a lot of real estate trading,  Brandon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now and then.  Mostly just for the  fun of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried it once.  I lost my shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a faint smile) I buy my shirts by the dozen.   Fortunately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glancing at the  elevator operator) Where did it all come from?  Or is  that a permissible question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elevator stops.  OTHER PEOPLE get in.  Elevator starts  down again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elevator reaches lobby floor, doors open, people come out Killaine and Brandon separately.  Brandon first.  He wait for Killaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a father who knew how to  steal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You asked me where it all came  from.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Oh.  That was just one of those  idle questions.  One doesn't expect  an answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon nods, turns towards the desk, Killaine following. Campbell the manager, is behind the desk, and a clerk.   The clerk, seeing Brandon, reaches mail out of the box,  hands it to Brandon, who stands looking over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Campbell) I think I'd like to take another  look at Mr. Mitchell's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon glances at him quickly, then back to his mail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know why.  As a matter of  fact, I don't know anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (polite but rather  cold) It's about time you did--know  something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I agree with you perfectly.  But  when did time ever help a fool?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon gives another quick glance, then strolls off alon the lobby towards the main Hotel entrance, still looking  at his mail as he walks.  Killaine looks after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine goes over to where Handley is sitting, drops int a chair beside him, takes out his crested cigarette case, takes a cigarette, then with an after-thought, offers cas to Handley, which brings then close together, as Handley  takes cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.  She hasn't shown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check the boat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gore's out doing it now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine gives him a light.  They both puff.  Killaine  pits cigarette case away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pretending to stifle  a yawn) Must be almost tea-time (moves to get up) I'll be in Mitchell's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Handley nods slightly.  Killaine gets up, starts to move  back to the desk.  Campbell stands there waiting for him.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY WALKING CAMERA FOLLOWING
dialogues.text: Her hands are deep in the pockets of her coat, head bent  forward.  She comes under a street sign, looks up.  The  sign says: FRONT STREET SOUND of a car coming up behind her.  SOUND indicates it  is breaking to stop.  Betty becomes rigid, then very slow turns her head, as though she expected to find a police  car had come up behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hop in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Showing Brandon's convertible, Brandon leaning out.  Bett crosses the sidewalk, gets into the car.  HOLD ON THE CAR as it starts up, SHOOTING FROM A NATURAL ANGLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hated to go to that place.  I  almost went to the police station  instead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No percentage in that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're going to arrest me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  Killaine has a warrant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as the car turns  into Ford Street) I have my own warrant.  Stop a  minute, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon looks at her, puzzled, brings the car to a stop;  sits staring at her.  Background of harbor ships, Betty  draws something out of her pocket--a paper--and hands it  to him.  He takes it, opens it, reads it aloud, in a low  voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading aloud) "Dear Inspector Killaine: This is  goodbye.  You were right, I had a  secret.  You were right, I changed  my name.  I tried to hide from the  past and I walked into almost the  same situation that I had run away  from.  I didn't kill Larry Mitchell,  but I can't prove it.  I couldn't  prove it the other time, either.   Where I am going, nothing has to  be proved.  There's a lot of water  between Vancouver and the U.S.A.  In  that, and in you.  Vancouver  has been kind to me.  I think you  will understand.  Betty Mayfield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon stops reading, his face is tight, and grim.  Slow he refolds the note and turns to look at Betty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you meant it, you wouldn't show  it to me, Betty. (pause) Or am I supposed to deliver it to  dear Inspector Killaine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a half-wild  tone) Wrote it in the waiting room of  the Hudson Bay Store.  With  somebody's Pekingese trying to  climb into my lap.  Perhaps you're  right.  Perhaps I didn't mean it.   All I know is that I'm licked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very slowly) There's a lot of water between  Vancouver and the U.S.A. This note  is a suicide note.  After you're  gone where would they look for  you? (long pause) Why would they look for you?   Darkness, and open water, and a  fast cabin cruiser.  And I have a  pocket full of money.  And if I  helped you, I'd be committing a  crime, or so they tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That wasn't why I called you.  Why  did I hope--when I hadn't any right  to hope?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How bad is it?  Bad enough for-- (he taps pointing  to the note)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  I've never been very far  from it, for a long time.  Will  you do something for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take me where I haven't the courage  to take myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How bad is the other thing?  The  secret?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was tried for murdering my  husband.  Guilty.  The judge set  the verdict aside.  There was one  man on the jury-- (she pauses, shakes  her head) --but he was afraid.  They were  all afraid--of my father-in-law.   That man followed me last night-- he came from him of course.  My  father-in-law will never give up.   Never.  He promised me that. (she laughs a little) So I came to Vancouver, B.C. As  far away as I can get from North  Carolina.  And it happens all over  again.  Almost the same thing.   Almost the same way.  Do you wonder  about this--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reaches to take the note from his hand.  He pulls it  away from her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the ace, Betty.  But not  of spades.  They'll find out about  the other.  They might know already.   And when they get this-- (he holds up the  note again) What would they look for?  Where?   Out there somewhere? (he points towards  the open water  beyond the ships)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll look for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I run over to Victoria.  Play some  golf with some people I know.  Do  it all the time.  That's why I  have a cabin cruiser.  Custom- built.Forty knots.  Mr Clark Brandon  an almost gentleman of almost  complete leisure.  Member of six  golf clubs.  Broke 70 once on the  Shaughnessy Heights Course.  You  have to be good to do that, And if  you look out of a front window of  the Empress Hotel in Victoria, in  a few hours you can look right  down on Mr. Brandon's boat, the  Valkyrie.  Came alone?  Sure.  He  always comes alone.  Mr Brandon's  a rather lonely man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staring at him,  fascinated) And Betty Mayfield--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blonde, beautiful, and sad--and  nowhere.  Of course she might have  run away--if she knew how.  And  where to go.  She might have dyed  her hair.  Bleached it before  probably. (Betty nods) And changed her name again.  But  look at this note. (he holds it up) And look at her room in the hotel.   Her stuff is all there.  Hasn't a  rag except what she stood up in.   You don't run away like that.  Not  if you are young and beautiful.   No chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (catching a little  enthusiasm from  him) But that's what I'm doing.  Couldn't  they think of that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they had any reason to.  Why  make it tough for themselves?  Why  go to all that trouble?  Here's an  open book.  Close it.  No reason  to keep it open.  She was a nice  girl, anyway.  And perhaps she  didn't kill him on purpose.  Perhaps  she didn't kill the other one.   You never know.  Give her the  benefit of the doubt.  Leave her  stay where she is.  Close the book.   Finis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The best interference runner we've  got.  He thinks he's in love with  you--and he's a gentleman.  Come  here, baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls her towards him, holds her in his arms, and kiss her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not.  Or I wouldn't be doing  this right now. (softly) Even if I didn't like you, I'd  have to do it.  Like the guy that  was dealt thirteen spades in a  bridge hand.  Or filled an ace- high flush.  You couldn't get him  out of that game to give him the  Pulitzer Prize.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pull apart.  Brandon starts the car again.  As it  gets into motion, he looks forward through the windshield brakes suddenly, with a grim expression.

dialogues.speaker: SHOOTING FORWARD THROUGH THE WINDSHIELD OF THE CAR
dialogues.text: Along the block, at the end of which is Charlie's Place. The sign can be made out vaguely.  A police car stands in front of the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with forced  carelessness) Must be raid day at Magruder's.   They always raid him before he  opens, so he won't lose any  business.

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR OF THE CAR
dialogues.text: As Brandon turns it in a fast U-Turn, CAMERA PANS IT OUT

dialogues.speaker: THE POLICE CAR IN FRONT OF MAGRUDER'S.
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT of the Police car - uniformed CHAUFFEUR at the wheel.  One of the car doors is standing open.

dialogues.speaker: THE ENTRANCE OF CHARLIE'S
dialogues.text: Another uniformed COP is standing at the door.  He pushes the door open, looks inside, up the staircase.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CHARLIE'S PLACE
dialogues.text: As seen before, except that the place is now tidied up,  the tables are in order, arranged for the night.  A door  at the back opens and a PLAIN CLOTHES DICK, one we have  not yet seen, comes through, starts walking rapidly in th direction of the street stairs.  Through the open door we HEAR Driscoll's voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not too loud) I want a man from the I-Bureau  down here as soon as possible.   There's some stuff in the waste  basket I'm afraid to handle.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CHARLIE'S PLACE
dialogues.text: As Driscoll replaces phone, turns to face Magruder, who i handcuffed, with a Man standing beside him.  Magruder is  scowling.  Driscoll brings up his left hand, showing on a spread handkerchief the sawed-off belly gun that Magruder took away from Goble and put in his desk drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What always throws me about people  like you is that you're so stupid.   Don't you know these things have  numbers on them?  And that they  have to be registered if they're  owned legally?  And that if we  find a man dead with his pocket's  empty--and identify him and find  out he's a private detective from  San Francisco--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tough) It needs music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring him and  continuing right  on) All we have to do is call the San  Francisco Police and get numbers  for his guns.  For the love of the  Saints, Magruder, if you're going  into the murder business, why don't  you learn a few rules?  You must  have been pretty desperate to move  him out of here in broad daylight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Magruder reacts.  This one catches him right square on th point of the chin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Don't you know we have people down  in the district working for us?   They might look like tramps to  you, and some of them are.  But  they have eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hoarsely) The guy pulled a gun on me.  I  thought it was a stick-up.  I hit  him with a sap.  Why wouldn't I?   Maybe I hit him too hard, and it  scared me.  I wanted to get him  away from here.  A guy like me  don't always get believed by guys  like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You had over sixteen hundred dollars  in your pocket, a thousand of them  in twenty-dollar bills.  With a  kind of new look about them at  that.  Would you be interested in  what I think about this, Magruder?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Magruder doesn't answer.  He is beginning to look very  groggy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply to the  other dick) Hold him.  He's trying to sag on  us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other dick straightens Magruder up, pushes him agains the wall.  Magruder's eyes are rolling in his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mercilessly) This man Goble rented the car,  gave a false name.  He had no  licence, no identification.  But  he put up a sufficient deposit.   He was a suspicious man.  He was  on a dubious errand.  He had a gun  in his pocket and I'm thinking one  of these manila envelopes-- (he points to the  waste basket) Contained those sheets of blank  paper which he was going to sell  for money.  And get out before  anybody looked at what he'd sold.   You had the money, Magruder.  But  you didn't give it to him.  You  killed him instead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Magruder starts to sag again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (more gently) Perhaps you didn't mean to kill  him.  But here he was dead, and  his car was outside in the street.   So you brought it around to the  alley and you carried the man down  to it, and you drove him away.   And what happened to him after  that, nobody knows until he was  picked out of the water of the  Sound, dead.  But not long dead.   Where did you leave the car,  Magruder?  Who helped you?  What  boat did you have? (pauses. His voice  changes to a dry  business-like tone  addressing the  other dick) All right.  Take him in.  Set him  down.  Give him what he wants to  make him comfortable.  And get a  stenographer.  And warn him.  And  don't rough him.  He's a nice little  man.  All he wants is to collect  his thoughts.  And then he'll tell  us the whole story in his own words. (his voice becomes  positively corny) Won't you, Magruder, darling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Magruder pitches forward to the floor in a dead faint.   The two detectives stand looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (somberly) He'll be giving the priest a bad  time, this one.  Maybe You'd better  call an ambulance.  He might have  a wonky ticker.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: CAMERA PICKS OUT BRANDON'S SEDAN which has just parked.   Brandon and Betty are getting out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over this way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start towards the corner of the building away from  the entrance.

dialogues.speaker: BUILDING
dialogues.text: Brandon stops at the padlocked door, unlocks it, opens it They start through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The seaward end is open, a big cabin cruiser is moored in the slip, a wooden ladder going down to it.  Brandon goes down the ladder to deck of cruiser, steadies it by pullin on the line, helps Betty down, then down into the cockpit

dialogues.speaker: SHOOTING DOWN THE SHORT COMPANIONWAY
dialogues.text: Brandon loads Betty down the companionway to the cabin of the cruiser.  It is paneled, with curtained windows,  luxurious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be safe here.  I won't be  long. (puts a bunch of  keys on the table) Help yourself to anything you want.   The galley's through there. (he points to a  door up forward) You can make coffee if you like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking around  here) This must have cost a fortune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It did, but it never paid off-- until now. (he looks at his  watch) I ought to be back within an hour.   We can't leave until near dark  anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have to leave the note?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the frame on the picture.   But not if you say so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes the note out of his pocket and holds it out.   Betty doesn't touch it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd still go through--even if I  ended up in jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't like it.  I've been  there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) My father died in jail, and he was  twice the man I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty just stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding up the  letter) Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a choked voice) You leave it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns away quickly, Brandon stands a moment, looking  at her, then turns back and EXITS SCENE.

dialogues.speaker: SHOOTING FORWARD THROUGH POLICE CAR WINDSHIELD
dialogues.text: Police radio is on.  From it we HEAR:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C.V.P.L. Vancouver Police  Department.  Repeating.  All points  Bulletin No.  611.  General alarm.   Wanted for questioning.  A young  woman.  American.  Using the name  Betty Mayfield, formerly Elizabeth  Kinsolving of Greenwater, North  Carolina.  Height five feet one  and a half inches.  Weight 118  pounds.  Hair blonde, may be dyed  darker.  Blue eyes.  Slender build.   Size 4AA shoes.  Quiet refined  manner.  Any person answering this  description should be held,  Communicate immediately with  Superintendent J. McKechnie,  Vancouver City Police, Vancouver,  B.C., for F.P. Classification.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A handsome table radio, Gore standing beside it.  The  continuation of broadcast in previous scene, without brea but with a difference in tone, due to the different  instrument.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outlying cities and towns please  rebroadcast.  Coast Guard stations  please rebroadcast.  Suspect may  attempt to cross border.  C.V.P.L.  Vancouver City Police, Vancouver,  B.C. I will repeat this bulletin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gore reaches across, shuts the radio off, turns, CAMERA  PULLS BACK TO A WIDER SHOT OF MITCHELL'S ROOM which is no typical, not very expensive hotel room, but with some  personal furniture such as table lamps, a shelf of books, a few indications that this has become the home of someon Gore moves towards the bed, Killaine is going through the contents of a suitcase.  He has underwear, shirts, socks, etc., spread out all around the bed cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She didn't seem the type to lam  out--even if she got the chance.   That stuff was all gone through  last night.  Anything special you're  looking for, Inspector?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll know when I find it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I'm just ballast around  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine doesn't answer.  He straightens up with a very  fancy thin gold cigarette case in his hand.  He opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get those from rich women--if  you are the kind of guy Mitchell  was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine dumps the cigarettes out of the case and holds  the inside against the light.  His gaze becomes fixed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) "G.G. Market one-eight-four-two."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi, huh?  Sounds French--one of  those fancy ladies.  Must have  been very fancy, if he scratched  her phone number in gold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring him,  speaking to himself) Market... It seems to me that's a  San Francisco exchange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon is seated at a small table, with a bottle and gla of beer in front of him.  He takes Betty's suicide note  out his pocket, reads it.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA MOVES IN ENOUGH TO SHOW WHAT HE IS READING
dialogues.text: He refolds it, holds it a moment, lost in thought, then  puts it away in his pocket, glances at his wrist watch,  stands up, starts out of scene, leaving beer almost  untasted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Killaine comes in He moves noiselessly around the room glancing at this and that, goes closet, comes back with a over-night case, which he puts on the bed.  It is locked. He gets out a bunch of keys, tried two or three, opens it He searches inside the over-night bag and comes up with a packet of travelers checks.

dialogues.speaker: THICK WAD
dialogues.text: Killaine replaces them in the over-night bag, re-locks it puts it back  in the closet, starts out towards balcony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty is stretched out on a bunk, smoking, NOISE is HEARD off, CREAKING WOOD STEPS.  She jumps to her feet, starts  towards the companionway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Brandon comes down off ladder and Betty comes up  companionway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tightly) Killaine's wise.  We can't wait  any longer.  Here, put this on. (he opens locker,  picks out an oilskin  coat, hand sit to  her) But stay out of sight until we  clear the harbor.  I'll tell you  when. (gets another oilskin  out of the locker,  puts it on himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine's wise to what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without answering, Brandon slips past her, down  companionway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Brandon enters, peeling off his overcoat and jacket,  tosses overcoat and hat aside, opens locker with push-bac door, hangs jacket up inside, takes out a heavy sweater  which he slips on, then a seamen's pea-jacket which he  also puts on.  He reaches far in and comes out holding a  .38 automatic, slips it into the inside pocket of the pea jacket, pulls locker door closed, starts out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty has put on her oilskin coat as Brandon comes up  companionway, slips behind the wheel and starts the motor He yells something at her, but the roar of the motors dro it out.  He points. She nods, goes back down companionway Brandon casts off, cruiser starts to back out of the slip

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cruiser backs in towards CAMERA, swings around, starts in a wide curve towards the harbor entrance, moving very fas Brandon alone is seen.  The cruiser picks up still more  speed and head off into the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elevator comes up, opens, Campbell and Gore come out.   Campbell crosses to penthouse door, presses bell, then  turns to Gore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm getting a little tired of this,  Sergeant.  Mr. Brandon's a valued  guest in this hotel.  We've known  him for a long time.  I don't like  this prowling into people's rooms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He presses the bell again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many people in your hotel know  a man was murdered here,  Mr.Campbell?  Apart from you and  the people questioned?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shortly) None, as far as I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you don't like our methods,  huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell gives him a look, takes out the passkey, and  unlocks door, starts in.  Gore moves past him, turns and  blocks him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all.  Thanks, Mr. Campbell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I insist--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all.  Thanks, Mr. Campbell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes the door shut, pushing Campbell out with it.  H puts on the night latch, grins and starts across living  room to French doors to terrace.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Killaine standing, looking up at end wall towards the wal of the penthouse terrace.  He looks down at the chaise on which Mitchell's body was found.  He goes to it, wheels i over so it is close to the end wall.  His eyes measure th distance from the chaise up to the top of the parapet wal of the penthouse terrace.  Gore appears IN THE SHOT ABOVE He looks down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling up to him) I'm coming up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes down to the corner of the balcony wall, steps up  on it, steadying himself with a hand against the steep en wall.  He turns his body so that he is standing sideways, rather unsteadily, and reaches up.  His hands are about  two feet short of being able to reach the top of the wall at which Gore stands.  Killaine gathers himself for a jum springs, catches the top of the wall with one hand, swing outwards, glances down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheer drop of 100 feet to the stone terrace outside the  hotel lobby.

dialogues.speaker: ABOVE
dialogues.text: Gore reaching down for him.  Killaine's body swings in  again.  With a jerk he gets the other hand up, laboriousl pulls himself up, and walks up the wall, CAMERA FOLLOWS  HIM.  Gore reaches to help him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tightly, straining  with effort) I'm all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets a leg over the penthouse wall, breathing hard.

dialogues.speaker: THE VIEW BELOW
dialogues.text: Gore is standing by the wall, Killaine astride of it.  He gets over to the balcony floor, stands up, wipes his hand off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaken) That's pretty risky business,  Inspector.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody did it twice last night-- in the dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points down.  Gore looks over the wall, downwards. WHAT HE SEES. Portion of Betty's balcony and the chaise almost directly below him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once to put that in the position  where it is now.  And the second  time to move it where we found it.

dialogues.speaker: KILLAINE AND GORE
dialogues.text: On the balcony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not too hard, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staring at him) Maybe we've been pretty dumb--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) There wasn't any motive...let's  try out the act.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gore steps back.  Killaine puts his hand in his pocket an brings out a gun, which looks very like the death gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a gun.  It's not loaded.   Pretend it is.  I'm drunk.  I took  the gun away from Margo West.  Now  I've said something to you that  you don't like.  I don't like the  look in your eyes, either.  I've  pulled the gun.  Take it away from  me.  And while you're taking it  away from me, it goes off.  Ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gore nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gore suddenly swarms him.  There is a brief sharp struggl Gore gets his hand over the gun.  It goes down as they  fight for it.  Gore turns it in toward Killaine's body.   There is a sharp click.  Gore steps back with the gun in  his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was that about the right angle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the shell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should be over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Points to the angle of the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pick it up.  Put it in your pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gore pretends to do so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same with the gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gore puts the gun in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got a dead man on your hands.   You killed jim--even if it wasn't  murder.  What are you going to do  about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I've got any sense I'm going to  call headquarters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll probably believe you.  But  they'll want to know what you were  fighting about.  Why Mitchell had  a gun.  You'll tell them a simple  story.  They'll pretend it sounds  all right to them.  Now you're  headquarters.  How does it sound  to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before I took the story and closed  the case, I'd want to know a lot  more about these people.  I'd want  to know just about everything about  them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) Exactly.  Now I'm the killer.  And  there's something I don't want you  to know.  Something that would  destroy my comfortable life, rob  me of my friends, my position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Such as?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Assume there is something to hid.   I go to a lot of trouble.  What do  I do?  What would you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I know who lives down there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I know that she's out of the  room?  Likely to be out of it for  some time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can find out the first part.   The second part you have to take a  chance on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty big chance, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got a dead man on your hands.   Like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He allows himself to collapse down on the floor, against  the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bends down over Killaine, gets a fireman's lift on him get's him up, drapes him over the wall, half on one side  and half on the other, his head and shoulders on the insi He straightens up, takes a firm grip on Killaine's wrists and eases him down over the wall.  Gore's head and should follow until he is lying across the wall on his stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Showing Killaine's body dangling directly over the chair. Gore comes as far down as he can.  Killaine has only a fe feet to fall.  Killaine looks down, then up at Gore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gore releases his wrists.  Killaine sprawls down on the  chaise, almost rolls over it, saves himself, lies down on his side.  Gore climbs over the wall, lowers himself, han by his hands, looks down, lets go with one hand, drops,  lands rather heavily on the balcony near the chaise, goes down on his hands and knees.  He stands up, dusts himself off, lifts the chaise with Killaine on it, and wheels it  about six feet away to the position where it was found  with Mitchell's body.  Killaine stands up off the chaise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gore reaches into his pocket, takes out the gun and a mat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding the match  up) This is the shell. (tossing it over in  the corner) What about the gun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well.  What about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've handled it.  Mitchell's handed  it.  If I wipe it off, no suicide.   If I take it out and lose it, no  suicide.  If I leave it here....no  suicide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to find a way to handle  it, openly.  Like Brandon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doubtful again) How did he know he'd get the chance?   He couldn't have arranged it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He could have tried.  If he was up  there in the dark, listening, he'd  know when she came home, know when  she found Mitchell dead, know what  she did about it.  If she  telephoned, he'd probably hear  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she did give him the chance,  the way it worked out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If she didn't--if luck was against  him--he wipes the gun off, reaches  the wall up there--drops it on the  chaise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No suicide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did we ever really think it was  suicide?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You win, Inspector.  You win all  along the line.  Why didn't we  think of Brandon before--or did we-- some of us. (pause, then  answering himself) Yeah.  Of course you did.  When a  suspect thinks he's safe, you go  on letting him think he's safe.   Wait for a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And a motive--which we haven't  got.  So this could all be a dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gore nods silently.  Killaine reaches in his pocket, take out Mitchell's thin gold case, opens it, looks down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Market one-eight-four-two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up at Gore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greer and Goble in the Call  Building, San Francisco.  Just  like you thought...Two murders in  two days.  Different places,  different methods, different people.   Nothing connects them, but a  telephone number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) A think wire---but very, very  strong.  Let's get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they start out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cabin cruiser coming into SHOT at high speed.

dialogues.speaker: CABIN CRUISER
dialogues.text: Brandon is behind the wheel, Betty beside him.  She is  looking back over her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can still see the shoreline.   The moon is rising.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There would be a moon tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty shivers a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cold?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frozen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go down into the cabin and get  yourself a drink.  Careful how you  go, we're hitting the swell now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty starts to move from the seat towards the companionw

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Betty comes in.  The cruiser has begun to pitch and  roll.  She makes her way along the cabin.  The cruiser  gives a lurch, Betty is thrown off balance.  She grabs a  door handle.  Door is pulled open.  Clothes are seen hang inside.  The cruiser gives another lurch and Betty is thr the other way, almost into the closet.  Her hand plunges  in among  the clothes.  Her expression shows she has touc something that startles her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty separates clothes and we SEE an empty gun holster  hanging on a hook against the back wall of the closet.   She stands motionless, staring at it, then notices Brando jacket hanging untidily on a hook with the inside pocket  exposed and a corner of her own suicide note showing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and she draws the envelope from the pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Betty closes the closet door, crosses to bunk.  The  cruiser is pitching.  She stands holding the suicide note envelope finally turns it over, draws out the note, repla it.  Then with a quick movement, she starts towards  companionway.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TOWARDS THE BOILING WAKE
dialogues.text: Brandon is staring straight ahead of him, tight-lipped.   There is a DISTANT SOUND OF A PLANE.  Brandon looks up,  searching the sky without changing expression.  Betty com back up the companionway, sits down in a corner of the  seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I decided I didn't want a  drink...I'm beginning to wonder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wonder what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're doing all this just for  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That, and the fun of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you had to be back to  the hotel.  To leave my--my note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silently, Betty takes out the note and holds it towards  him.  Brandon glances at it.  He cocks his ear towards th PLANE NOISE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See anything up there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As betty looks up, he lets go of the wheel, and makes a  sudden grab for the wrist of the hand holding the note.   There is a short, sharp struggle.  Brandon has the note. The wheel swings wildly and the cabin cruiser keels over  into a hard turn.  Brandon thrusts the note into his pock grabs the wheel, wrenches it around, gets the cruiser goi on course again.  Betty leans in a corner of a seat, away from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny, I never thought of you that  way.  You were so close too.  We  were all pretty stupid about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tightly) Including Killaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Including Killaine...I still can't  think of you that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staring straight  ahead) I told you my father died in jail.   He stole a fortune.  Most of it  pretty dirty money.  I don't care  to have that known.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (same tone) Larry Mitchell found out.  So you  killed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it was an accident, you could  have told the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So could you.  But our records  were a little against us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What your father did doesn't condemn  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody believed I wasn't in on it.   I was just a dumb-smart collage  boy, and he was my father.  I  thought it was a legitimate  business.  He was a politician,  with fingers in a lot of pies.  I  never saw the pies.  They had names.   For the record.  Innocent names. (he shrugs) You know where that kind of money  comes from, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The money that makes you Mr. Clark  Brandon.  Let's you live in a  penthouse, on top of the Vancouver  Royal.  Lets you own a cruiser.   Lets you do as you please, go where  you please.  You big, open-handed,  generous guy.  That's the kind of  money it takes, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PLANE NOISE is a little LOUDER.  Brandon looks up at  it without much interest, then looks at Betty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It buys things, just like any other  kind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That man that was following us  last night--he didn't come back  this morning.  I'm beginning to  wonder about him, too.  Was he  really following me--or you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I paid him off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll come back...They always come  back when you give them money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not this one.  And not Mitchell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (recoiling) You-killed-him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a twisted  smile) Magruder obliged me.  No use my  saying it wasn't planned that way.   I had to clean up.  I'm not a dumb- smart college boy anymore. (he takes a deep  breath) Nobody in the world would believe  I didn't plan the whole thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I'm a little screwy.  Maybe  I could believe it.  Should I try?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't go soft on me, baby.  I've  got your note in my pocket.  You  wrote it, all by your own self.   And I have to use it.  It has to  be found in exactly the right place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So that I will never be found.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon turns his head and stares full at her.  He swallo He can't speak.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: The room is dark except for a strong white light over a  desk. In the background there is a projection screen and a  comparison projector.  The police technician is bending  over the desk looking at something through a magnifying  glass, as Killaine enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got anything on the Goble case  yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Technician puts down a magnifying glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I think so.  Here are two  glazed manila envelopes. (he holds them up) One is the bag type.  The other  one had the money in it.  Don't  ask me how I know.  I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm interested in who handled it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four different people, Inspector.   Three men and a women.  I've made  slides for two.  They handled both  envelopes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He fits two slides into the projector and switches on the light.  Focuses a couple of separate images on the screen One is a complete fingerprint, the other a portion such a would be made by a tip of a finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goble.  Second finger on left hand.   On the left, the morgue print.  On  the right, print lifted from the  envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns another knob and the two fingers draw together,  overlap, and coincide, so that the incomplete image  disappears altogether.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No doubt about that one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about Magruder?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He checks too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That leaves two strangers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try Betty Mayfield.  The Mitchell  case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised) Mayfield?  She fit into this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deadpan) She might.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Technician opens a file drawer and takes out a fingerprin card.  Lays it on the desk and picks up the magnifying  glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll have to take my word for  it.  We don't make slides until we  have perfect prints for comparison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take your word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Technician places another card beside the one he took from the drawer, bends over, examines them through the  magnifying glass, straightens up and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a chance.  Whorl and plain  arch. Different as salt and sand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine puts his hand in his pocket and takes out anothe fingerprint card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try this one for the second  stranger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Technician takes the card, looks at it, pushes the other  cards to one side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gun permit, huh? (he lines up two  cards, studies  them) Another Whorl--man size.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He studies the prints a moment longer, then faces Killain

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This gun permit was issued to Clark  Brandon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The card says so, doesn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon handled the money envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine turns instantly, and starts out, CAMERA FOLLOWIN As he opens the door, he meets Driscoll coming in.  Drisc backs away, Killaine exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the face for, Driscoll?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Magruder's conked out.  Adrenaline  injections, oxygen tent.  He may  come out of it and he may not.  As  a source of quick information, we  can't forget him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't need him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens door of I-Bureau.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on in.  See what they've got.   All I need now is a warrant and a  pair of wings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes out of SHOT quickly.  Driscoll looks after him,  then starts into I-Bureau.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is an armed guard at the entrance and a Canadian  Coast Guard flag flies over the building.  A Vancouver  police car drives up at high speed and squeals to a stop  beside the sentry.  Killaine leans out of the window, sho the sentry his badge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inspector Killaine.  Vancouver  City Police.  Commander Goodwin's  expecting me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steps back.  The police car speeds on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Radio operator at set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into mike) C.G.L. at all cutters and patrol  planes on station.  Vancouver Police  Department bulletin.  Wanted for  murder.  Clarke Brandon.  A  naturalized Canadian citizen.  Age  34-35.  Height six feet, one inch.   Weight 190 pounds.  Muscular build.   Dark hair.  American accent.  Now  probably at sea in cabin cruiser  Valkyrie.  Will probably attempt  to cross International line under  cover of darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Engines idling.  A rating stands by to cast off.  Killain and a Coast Guard officer come rapidly down ramp, jump on board.  Rating casts off.  Lynx, a converted P.T. boat,  without torpedo tubes, moves off from berth, picking up  speed rapidly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Traveling at high speed in open water. PLANE NOISE high overhead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon at wheel.  Betty pressed into corner of a seat  watching him.  Spray drifts over them.

dialogues.speaker: COAST GUARD PLANE IN FLIGHT
dialogues.text: A converted Hudson bomber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pilot and co-pilot can be seen through the Plexiglas. They are searching the water below with their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SHOOTING PAST PILOT AND CO-PILOT
dialogues.text: Pilot pushes the wheel forward and the plane goes into a  steep dive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cabin cruiser is seen far below, moving fast through  the water.  Or rather its wake is seen.  The cruiser itse at this height, is almost invisible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty is looking up at the plane.  Brandon reaches inside his coat.  His hand comes out with a heavy automatic, whi we have seen before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tightly) Get down in the cabin, Betty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her eyes go down.  She sees the gun, reacts.  A bitter  smile moves her lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?  To love ten minutes longer?   And in the meantime, protect you? (her voice becomes  taunting) Why don't you shoot me now and get  it over with--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: she looks up towards the PLANE NOISE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you think you have the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fog bank about a mile ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as if to himself) Always some fog out here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up in the direction of the PLANE NOISE which is  increasing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There better be.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT THROUGH THE PLEXIGLAS HEAD AND SHOULDERS OF THE PILO
dialogues.text: AND Co-PILOT. The cruiser down on the water is getting rapidly larger,  but still cannot be seen who is in the cockpit, or even  how may persons.  The co-pilot puts a pair of binoculars  to his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon with one hand on the wheel, the other holding the gun.  He is staring up towards the plane.  Betty is not i the cockpit.  Brandon turns towards where she was, reacts sharply, seeing she has disappeared.  An expression of  frustration and despair shows on his face for a moment.   The NOISE OF THE PLANE in the power dive becomes furiousl LOUD.  Brandon's head goes around again.

dialogues.speaker: THE PLANE DIVING DIRECTLY ON THE VALKYRI
dialogues.text: Brandon sees it.  It dives down almost into the CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: FROM WATER LEVEL
dialogues.text: The Valkyrie and the plane.  At the last moment, the plan pulls out of the dive, only thirty or forty feet above th Valkyrie, and goes into a climbing bank.

dialogues.speaker: VALKYRIE
dialogues.text: The fog bank is dead ahead.  The coast Guard plane is  climbing off to the left.  The Valkyrie reaches the fog  bank, plunges into it, and becomes invisible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon is steering straight ahead.  He reaches to cut of the engines.  The Valkyrie slows down.  Betty's head emer from the companionway.  Her eyes meet Brandon's.  Brandon is silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hoped I'd jumped overboard,  didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon does not answer, just stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I wouldn't make it that easy  for you.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGE OF LYNX
dialogues.text: Coast Guard Lt. in command.  Killaine beside him, a talke with a head-set standing nearby.  He is receiving a messa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into his mouthpiece) Bearing one-three-five. (to Coast Guard  officer) Bearing one-three-five, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coast Guard officer nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to helmsman) Get it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One-three-five, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns his wheel a little.  The Lynx changes course,  heeling over.  Coast Guard officer puts binoculars to his eyes, wings them in a slow arc.  They come to a stop, fix

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing) There!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine follows his pointing finger.

dialogues.speaker: HANGING IN THE SKY AND FALLING
dialogues.text: As it falls, it is swallowed in a bank of fog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tensely) Fog!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got a lot of it out here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon will have counted on that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No doubt.  We have something he  may not have counted on.

dialogues.speaker: CABIN CRUISER VALKYRIE IN FOG
dialogues.text: NOISE OF THE PLANE overhead, loud but diminishing.  Brand sits listening, his hand on the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (contempt in her  voice now) You'll never make it.  You've out- smarted yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (QUIETLY) I'm still on course to Victoria.   Nobody saw you get on board, nobody  seen you since.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Valkyrie has now stopped on the swell.  It rocks a  little.  There are confused NOISES in the distance.  PLAN NOISE, possibly some other kind of ENGINE NOISE.  In the  fog you can't tell what it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't leave the note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon puts the gun down close to his body, and pats his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't the time or place.  Don't  worry about the note, baby.  I'm  playing for my neck now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm begging for my life--and  yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (startled) Mine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  Yours.  You haven't murdered  anybody.  You killed Mitchell.   Wasn't that an accident?  It must  have been.  If you kill a  blackmailer, you kill him dead--so  that he can't talk anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitchell was dead enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that nasty man that followed  us last night.  You didn't kill  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who'd believe it but you?  I took  him out to sea and threw him in  the water.  Even if they find him,  what connects him with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Magruder does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think Magruder wants to hang  beside me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the next one is murder.  First  the little step, then the longer  step , and then the step you can  never take back.  You could tell  about Mitchell.  You could tell  about Magruder--and the detective.   It would hurt, but you could do  it.  You could never tell about  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would I want to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every day of your life you'll want  me.  You'll never get over it.   Every time you see your face in  the mirror--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a sudden burst  of fury) Shut up!  Cut it out!  Even if I  have to kill both of us--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He breaks off with a disgusted gesture.  A faint smile  shows on Betty's lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killaine and the Coast Guard officer are peering ahead  into the thick fog.  The Lynx is just drifting.  The  helmsman is standing on hand on the wheel.  The Coast Gua officer turns to the Talker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Talker shakes his head, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (SUDDENLY) Just a minute, sir.  I believe--

dialogues.speaker: RADAR SCREEN BELOW THE BRIDGE
dialogues.text: A blob of light takes the form in one corner of it.  CAME PULLS BACK TO INCLUDE THE RADAR OPERATOR.  He reaches for a mike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into mike) Change course about five degrees  south

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a moment the blob of light on the radar screen move towards the center of the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into mike) Your dead on now.  Hold it there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The four MEN on it are now tensely staring straight ahead

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon is listening again.  Far away there is a faint  SOUND OF DIESEL ENGINES, but growing rapidly louder.  He  stands up and twists his body, still holding the gun, loo back, then slips quickly behind the wheel again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Radar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He guns the motor and the cabin cruiser shoots forward  into high speed.  Betty has to hang on.  He swings the  cruiser around on another course and guns for it for all  its worth for a moment or two, then abruptly cuts the mot again.  Cruiser slows down, once more drifts.  The ENGINE SOUND has now stopped.  Brandon turns to face Betty, who  is now standing up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is it, Betty.  They'll find  us again, fog or no fog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (speaking slowly,  with difficulty) If it has to be--do you mind if I  do it myself? (pause, then quickly) Oh, I don't mean with the gun.   This is no trick.  When I wrote  that note you have in your pocket-- that was no trick either.  It's  not so hard for me as you think.   I'm not crying about it, I've been  skating close to it for quite some  time.  The water is cold down there-- (she gives a little  shrug) But so is everything else.  And  there's you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (startled) Me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  You.  You're not really a  murderer yet.

dialogues.speaker: RADAR SCREEN
dialogues.text: A Blob of light slides into it from another corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into his mouthpiece) Bearing one-eight-one. (to Coast Guard  officer) One-eight-one, sir.  Changed course  due South.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to helmsman) One-eight-one..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One-eight-one, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helmsman swings the wheel around.  The Lynx veers, heelin over, comes level again.

dialogues.speaker: DOWN ON LYNX, (FROM HELICOPTER)
dialogues.text: Following at an equal speed, then the Lynx gradually pull away into the fog and disappears.  The NOISE OF ITS ENGIN is still heard for a few moments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still motionless on the water idling.  There is a SOUND O THE CUTTER'S MOTORS, far off, but increasing.  Brandon is paying no attention.  He is staring at Betty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thickly) I'm not a murderer yet, you said.   Come here.  Come closer.  Let me  look at you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty holds off, then slowly comes towards him along the  seat, until their faces close.  He searches her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) I think you mean that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think I was faking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thickly) If I did-I don't-now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts his arms around her, pulls her close.  There is  kind of wonder in his eyes.  Hers stare back at him, calm and level.  He kisses her hard on the mouth, let's her go She pulls away from him, along the seat.  She doesn't kno what to think of him.  She is terrified, resigned, and at the same time, he still has an attraction for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kiss of death. (laughs) With a new twist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lifts the gun in his hand, looks at it, tosses it  overboard.  He reaches inside his coat, takes out the  suicide note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) "Dear Inspector Killaine.  This is  goodbye.  You were right.  I had a  secret."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DIESEL ENGINE SOUND has grown louder.  Brandon looks  up from the note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A secret, Betty---as who hasn't

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crumples the note and envelope in his hand, drops them over the side of the boat.  Opens the engine full throttl and the power of the cruiser almost tears it out from und them.  Betty is thrown violently against the seat.  He  reaches out and straightens her up.  There is a mad light in his eyes.  His face is no longer hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of the chase, alternating with the Cabin Cruiser and the  Lynx, as the Lynx gradually closes in.  During these shot Cabin Cruiser and the Lynx both come out of the fog bank  into moonlit water, but there is another fog bank half a  mile or so ahead.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT FROM BACK OF CRUISER
dialogues.text: The Lynx is moving up fast, and the Coast Guard officer  can be seen on the bridge, with binoculars to his eyes. rating, hanging on tight, is stripping the canvas off a  twin machine gun mount.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (above the roar of  the motors) Stand up!  Let them take a good  look at you.  Be sure they see  you.  That fellow back there has  night glasses.  Then jump---well  out to the side.  Just as far as  you can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty does what he tells her.  She waves.  There is an  answering wave from the bridge of the Lynx.  We can't see who's waving.  Betty sets herself to jump.  She tries to  speak to Brandon, but nothing comes out.  There is a grea deal of NOISE from motors.  Gravely, Brandon lifts his  hand and salutes her.  She jumps.

dialogues.speaker: PULLS AWAY RAPIDLY
dialogues.text: Towards another fog bank beyond the clear space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Full speed astern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Full speed astern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cutter heaves on reversed engines, nearly stands on  its tail in the water, drifts past Betty, comes to a stop then moves forward slowly, swinging around to get close t her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HIGH SHOT of Cabin Cruiser as it reaches the fog and plun into it.  HELICOPTER WITH CAMERA plunges into fog at the  same time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stopped on the swell.  Betty in the water, fighting her  way towards it.  A life belt and rope are dropped neatly  beside her.  She grabs it and is drawn towards the side o the lynx.  Coast Guard officer, Killaine, and a rating pu rope ladder over the side.  Killaine starts down the rope ladder.

dialogues.speaker: DOWN FROM THE DECK OF THE LYNX
dialogues.text: Past Killaine on the rope ladder to water, as Betty is  pulled to foot of ladder.  Killaine reaches down, gets he hand.  She grasps rope ladder, Killaine helps her up onto it.  Business of getting her on board cutter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon staring straight ahead of him, gripping the wheel hard, giving the cruiser everything it has, driving as if he had a clear, open course.  HEARS A FOGHORN, somewhere  of the fog.  Cocks his head, tries to gauge the direction Turns the wheel a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Betty comes over the side, Killaine holding her up,  Betty is shivering with cold.  The rating hauls up the  rope ladder and the life belt.  Coast Guard signals the  bridge ad the Lynx starts moving ahead again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Betty) Better get those wet clothes off  in a hurry, Miss.  My cabin's at  your disposal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.  Thank you very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He salutes, turns away, after giving a quick look at  Killaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Killaine) He could have killed me a dozen  times.  You'd never have known.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We know everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost passionately) No, Jeff.  You don't.  He's not a  murderer, I tell you.  He;s not a  murderer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (same tone) I hope he can prove it.  Come on.   You don't want to get pneumonia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes her arm, starts to push her along.  She is still shivering, but still determined to  defend Brandon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I tell you---if you'd only  understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently) I understand, Betty.  I understand  perfectly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts his arm around her.  Their eyes meet in a long  look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cruiser is moving at high speed in the fog.  The FOG  HORN SOUND is louder, but seems to come from all directio Brandon is leaning forward, tensely, trying to see ahead. He turns the wheel first one way, and then another.  Ther is a sudden blast of the FOGHORN, very LOUD. Brandon turns the wheel violently and the cruiser keels  over.  But he is now quick enough.  Suddenly above looms  the enormous bow of the Puget Sound Ferry, as big as an  ocean liner.  It is ablaze with light.  CAMERA PANS UP to show it crashing down into the lens as it were.

dialogues.speaker: THE CABIN CRUISER VALKYRIE
dialogues.text: Thrown out of the water almost, it is up-ended on its ste The ferry tears on through, filling the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple of PASSENGERS in overcoats leaning against the  rail looking out into the fog.  One of them is lighting a cigarette, cupping his hands around the lighter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You always have this kind of weather  up here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certain times of the year.  Always  a lot of fog.  But they never hit  anything, somehow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the end of the bridge an OFFICER is leaning down, star towards the water.  He shakes his head, straightens up,  turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (speaking off) An old packing case, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: A BIG SEARCHLIGHT
dialogues.text: Its beam is turned down on the water.  The beam moves a  little, back towards the stern.  CAMERA FOLLOWS THE BEAM  DOWN THROUGH THE FOG.  Empty water only is SEEN.  The  searchlight is switched off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A broken piece of the cabin cruiser's bow floats by, clos and closer to THE CAMERA, until on it the name VALKYRIE  stands out, then it whirls past.  There is nothing left  but the foggy surface of the Sound.
